Boris Johnson is said to be looking at new ways to relax the rules as part of a wider announcement on easing lockdown tomorrow. Tomorrowaposs address to Parliament was expected to cover the reopening of pubs and hairdressers on or after July  - and could relax the two-metre rule. Now the Dailyhas reported there are plans for a change to support bubbles too. Downing Street has not confirmed the plans and thereports there is no final decision. A senior government source confirmed ministers were considering allowing more social contact from July , but did not specythat would be in the form of bubbles or other social contact, such as gathering outdoors. The system has let two households in England join together permanently since June  - allowing people to break social distancing rules for the first time. The system has reunited kids with grandparents, and allowed some couples who live apart to have sex after three months away. But millions have also lost out due to tight rules on the scheme.  Currently bubbles must consist of two households only, and one of those households must have only one adult. Each household can also be in only one aposexclusiveapos bubble, forcing people to make dficult choices about whether to see a parent or a lover. A senior government source told the Daily : There will be an expansion of social bubbles, but the details are still being finalised.  One option is said to be letting two households join together, as with the current rules, but to scrap the limit on numbers in each household. A second option is set to be allowing a bubble of any number of households, but with a cap on the overall number of people in each bubble. A source told the : The question with bubbles has always been how you help families reunite to the maximum possible extent without too much risk. The scientistsapos main concern has always been infections spreading from one household to another, which is why this is one of the more dficult decisions we have to take. Boris Johnson is expected to announce lockdown easing plans to Parliament tomorrow lunchtime after consulting his Cabinet in the morning. The PM said he has been sticking like glue to his plan to start reopening the hospitality and leisure sector from July  - including pubs, restaurants, cafes, hotels, cinemas, hairdressers and more. But itaposs likely not all sectors will reopen at once, due to the danger of pushing aposRapos - the number of people each Covid- carrier infects - above one. Rules will be tightened in some areas, with ministers looking at making people register when they enter a pub to make contact-tracing easier. And No warned any widespread breaches would lead to this weekaposs changes being axed first.

Since March millions of clinically vulnerable people have been shut indoors practically the whole time, until recently not even leaving for exercise. Now a plan to unlock those doors - in two stages on July  and August  - has been revealed by the government. From July  shielding people can go out and meet up to five friends - andthey live alone, form a aposbubbleapos with another household. From August , the advice to shield ends completely. Health Secretary Matt Hancock announced: Now, with infection rates continuing to fall in our communities, our medical experts have advised that we can now ease some of these measures, while keeping people safe. But charities warn there is too much dangerous ambiguity and people could have vital support withdrawn - or feel forced back to work unsafely. Sick pay and a system of food deliveries will end on July  - which campaigners fear could leave shielded people in the lurch. So what are the changes announced today and what are the implications for you and the ones you love  Hereaposs the announcement explained.What has the government announced today  The government has announced major changes to the .million people in England who have been asked to shield from coronavirus. Since March, those deemed aposextremely clinically vulnerableapos to Covid- were asked to stay in their homes and not leave at all, even for exercise. Those rules lasted until June  and have remained unchanged, apart from a big tweak on June . This tweak allowed shielded people to go outside for the first time - either with their household or,they live alone, with one person . It was criticised for being announced on a Saturday night by Boris Johnson without full details.  Who is supposed to aposshieldapos  The aposshieldingapos group in England is .million people classed as extremely clinically vulnerable, who were specically advised to stay at home at all times due to Covid-. A full list is here, butyou are in the shielded group you should have been contacted directly. People received the advicethey have a condition that makes them vulnerable to contracting or becoming seriously ill from Covid-. It includes people undergoing chemotherapy or radiotherapy, anyone with cystic fibrosis or COPD, or those with signicant heart conditions. There is a misconception that shielded people are over  - this isnapost true. Some shielding people are over , but not all. Some over-s are shielding, but not all. Is shielding compulsory  No - there is no law forcing people to shield but it is advised for their own protection. The government says there is a package of protective measures, including a helpline and food deliveries, to help people who canapost rely on friends and neighbours for supplies.  What will change from July   From Monday  July, there will be two major changes for all .million people who are shielding in England. Firstly, people who are shielding will be able to join gatherings of up to six people outdoors. These gatherings can be from up to six dferent households - but anyone from separate households must maintain a -metre distance. This follows the rules that were unveiled for the rest of England from June . Secondly, people who are shielding and live alonewill be able to join the apossupport bubbleapos system topair up permanently with one other household. They will be able to break the two-metre rule with people inside their bubble to hug and kiss. This follows the same rules as the current bubble system outlined on June . In other words, one of the two households - the shielded household - must be a single-adult household. Each household can only bubble up with one other household.  What will change from August   From Saturday  August, the .million clinically vulnerable people in England will officially be told they no longer have to shield from the virus. It will bring to an end a period of isolation lasting more than four months. While they should strictly follow social distancing rules, they will be able to go back to workthey cannot work from home, and visit shops and places of worship. Will shielding support end on August   Not completely - but a lot of it will. The governmentaposs direct food parcel and medicine deliveries will end. Matt Hancock confirmed they “continue to the end of July”. And shielding people will no longer be paid Statutory Sick Pay - unless they develop symptoms or are told to isolate. That brings them in line with the rest of the population. The government claims help wonapost simply end at the stroke of midnight on July . NHS Volunteer Responders will still be able to help with collecting shopping or medication, a regular friendly phone call, or transport to appointments. Shielding people will also retain their priority for supermarket delivery slots. But Nick Moberly, Chief Executive of the MS Society, warned: “We are gravely concerned that certain key support measures – such as food packages and Statutory Sick Pay – will be taken away prematurely. Without this help, and with many people still terried of infection, for some the idea of normal le ing will feel more like a threat than an opportunity. WhatIaposm scared toto work on August   Itaposs up to you and your employer - not the government. This is likely to prompt a major row from campaigners who want guaranteed legal protection for workers. The government press release says: From  August, those who need to work and cannot do so from home will be able toto work as long as their workplace is COVID secure, adhering to the  guidance available. But it does not say what will happenpeople feel too frightened or clinically vulnerable to go back. And government sources confirmed this would be a conversation between a worker and their employer - rather than a set legal protection. Health Secretary Matt Hancock told employers: We expect you to do the right thing. Nick Moberly, Chief Executive of the MS Society, warned: “Those who now may have no choice but toto work must be given the right information so that – together with their employer – they can ensure their working environment is safe. We also need clarity on what ‘carefully following social distancing’ means in the real world, in situations like shopping or meeting friends. There is still far too much room for interpretation, and this ambiguity could put people in danger. So are shielded people now under the same rules as other people in England  No. Between July  and August , there are only specic changes. Shielding isnapost being lted completely at that point. Shielded people are still advised not to go to the shops. To make things more confusing, while the aposbubbleapos and aposgroup of six outdoorsapos rules will currently bring shielding people in line with the rest of England, this might not last. Both those rules might be changed for the rest of England - the non-shielding - by the time they come into effect for the .million people who are shielding. We donapost know yet, but itaposs possible. From August , shielding people are still advised to continue to follow strict social distancing measures so the rules are more or less the same as the non-shielded. But they are still at higher risk.  Whatmy family already bubbled up with someone  in June  Then youaposre a bit stuck. Single-adult households in the rest of England have already been able to bubble up with one other household since June . But households are only meant to pick one bubble buddy and stick with that one, not switch around. This meansyou, a family of four, have already decided to bubble up with your non-shielded sister, you shouldnapost then bubble up with your shielded dad. Could I end up having to shield all over again  Yes,there is a second wave of the pandemic. Health Secretary Matt Hancock said the shielding list will be maintained and “we stand ready to support people to shield againthat is what’s clinically required”. Mr Hancock also said there could be local shielding ordersthe virus flares up in one particular city. “We will have the ability to do that and we’d consider that as part of a local lockdownthat is what was clear advice, he told the Mirror.

This yearaposs exams were cancelled completely due to the pandemic. The current timetable says next yearaposs exams start in May  and must end before a contingency day of  June . But Tory MP Alec Shelbrooke askedthe entire season in England could be pushed back into July.He said it would allow students and teachers more time in the classroom to try and complete the curriculum. Answering him in the Commons, Mr Williamson said the MP had raised an important point about how do we add more teaching time in. It came as Mr Williamson insisted he was planning for a fullof every single child in every year group from September. Scotland and Wales are bringing back some pupils on a rota or part-time to avoid the spread of the virus. But Mr Williamson - who will outline a full plan for September next week - insisted he was planning for a fullof every single child in every year group back into school.  Boris Johnson has insisted he wants all children back in school five days per week from September.He said last week he did not want part-time learning or half days, adding: “I’m making no bones about it, I think that’s the way forward for our country. This could cause chaosthere is an outbreak, becauseone pupil tests positive for Covid- all those in the same bubble would have to isolate for two weeks. Boris Johnsonaposs official spokesman said: The PM is determined that children should be back in school in September and we want to do everything we possibly can to deliver that. “It’s important that children attend school and we don’t want them missing out on the benefits and the value of education”. Askedhaving children back in class five days a week was government policy, the spokesman said: The Education Secretary will publish a plan but you’ve got the PM’s words from Friday. He was pretty clear he wants all kids back in schools in September. Mr Williamson last week unveiled a £billion catch-up fund for schools.  Today Shadow Education Secretary Rebecca Long-Bailey slammed the fund for not including nurseries or colleges - despite an early wrong press release claiming it would. She said: Less than an hour later the Government amended the press release. The funding was not for early years and -, it was £ million, not £ million, it would not be available until September and now I hear that schools will need to find % of tuition funding themselves. So I ask the Secretary, what on Earth happened   Mr Williamson replied: There is a reality - that this side of the House is committed to getting every child back into school and we understand that actually this is where they are going to benefit from. If it was up to the party opposite we wouldnapost see any children back into the classroom, but what weaposve already got, weaposve got nursery back, weaposve got reception back, weaposve got Year  back, weaposve got Year  back, weaposve got Year  back and weaposve got .

title: commuters arent wearing face masks
story: NewsCommuters arent wearing face masks properly on public transport, expert warnsProfessor Susan Michie says training may be needed to ensure face coverings are worn properly as those who do not wear them correctly put themselves and others at risk of contracting coronavirusShareCommentsByNisha MalJamie Hawkins:,  JUN NewsAn expert has warned people may have to be taught how to wear face masks correctly [file image] " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPeople arenapost wearing face masks properly on public transport, an expert has warned.It is now mandatory for anyone using public transport to wear a face covering to help contain the spread of coronavirus.The new law, which started on June , meant anyone not wearing a face covering on public transport could be fined £ in England. But according to Professor Susan Michie, a member of the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies’subgroup on behavioural science, some people do not know how to correctly put a face mask on and are putting themselves and other commuters at risk.  According to the gov.uk website, a face covering “should cover your mouth and nose while allowing you to breathe comfortably”, YorkshireLive reports.“Wash your hands or use hand sanitiser before putting it on and after taking it off,” the website advises. “Avoid touching your eyes, nose or mouth at all times and store used face coverings in a plastic bag until you have an opportunity to wash them. “Do not touch the front of the face covering or the part of the face covering that has been in contact with your mouth and nose. Once removed, make sure you clean any surfaces the face covering has touched.” However, Prof Michie says many people appear to be wearing their face coverings below the nose and holding the front of items to remove them, rather than using the straps behind the head. She told The Sunday : “Any time one goes out and around in parks and down the street this is the sort of thing you see.” Prof Michie added a national campaign might be needed to “train” people on how to wear their face coverings correctly.  “I think the main thing is that where you have a behaviour that requires some kind of skill, and some kind of routine and procedure to make it effective, then usually it’s not enough to say do this, ie transmit knowledge, but we also need to have training. “If it’s a question of skills, ie the behaviour surrounding the putting on, off and wearing of , then it does require skills training.”Last week, Mayor of London Sadiq Khan warned Brits may have to wear face masks for the next year. He told LBC: This is part of the new normal. For the foreseeable future, I believe for the next year or so, wearing face coverings is going to become the norm rather than the exception. I was pleased when the PM accepted the need for us to wear face coverings on public transport, and make it mandatory.

title: devastated dad weeps fathers day
story: NewsDevastated dad weeps on Fathers Day for his three little angels killed in fireGrief-stricken Alex Gibson had popped to a garage to buy snacks for his children on Friday night and came home to a fire ripping through the family home in PaisleyShareCommentsByJohn DingwallKelly-Ann Mills:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsAlex Gibson arrived at the scene of the house fire which cost the lives of his children and broke down in tears " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA dad cried as he read tributes at the scene of a flat fire where his three young children died.Grief-stricken Alex Gibson arrived at the gutted family home on Fathersapos Day, to remember his daughter Fiona,  and his sons Alexander James, eight and Philip, five.The trio died after a blaze ripped through an upper cottage flat in Paisley, on Friday night, the Daily Record reports.The children’s mum Julie Daley remained in a critical condition in the intensive care unit at Paisley’s Royal Alexandra Hospital on Sunday.Alex ed briefly to the scene of the tragedy yesterday afternoon to see what little was left of the home. For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, click here   He knelt down at the floral tributes to read cards and look at soft toys, including teddy bears and unicorns, which had been left by dozens of friends and neighbours. The touching message on one card read: “To Fiona, my bestie forever. Thank you for the great memories we made together. You showed me exactly what a best friend is. “I will miss you very much. It’s never goodbye, just a see you soon. All my love, Hayley xoxoxo.” At one stage, the heartbroken dad looked up at the burned-out flat and wept uncontrollably.  He was supported by family members and escorted by two police family liaison officers as he left after the painful visit.The dad, who loved making TikTok videos for his children and who hoped to go to Florida with them when lockdown  was over, was too upset to speak. Expressing his grief on social media, he posted: “How I miss them already. Now I know what it feels like when your world comes crashing down.” It followed an earlier message from the distraught dad, which read: “Rest in peace u little angels.” Alex had walked to the nearby Esso garage on Friday night to buy sweets and crisps for his children, only toand find the family home engulfed in flames at about pm. The Scottish Fire and Rescue said six crews who rushed to the scene were met with a “well developed” blaze in the first-floor property. The three children were taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in  Glasgow. All three were pronounced dead a short time after being admitted.Detectives went door-to-door yesterday as they talked to neighbours moments before Alex arrived at the scene. A police spokesman said: “An investigation is under way to establish the exact circumstances of this incident.  “Anyone who has information that could assist our inquiries should contact police via  quoting incident number  of June , .” A fundraising page has been set up for the family and was on course to double its target just over  hours after it was started by a friend. She was hoping to raise £, to help the family “who have lost everything”. That target was quickly exceeded, with the total raised reaching £, last night.

title: four devastating ways black brits
story: NewsFour devastating ways black Brits health is suffering because of racismWere looking at some of the biggest issues affecting black lives in Britain todayShareCommentsByAdenike Adenitire:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsMirror writer Adenike Adenitire with her dad Emmanuel, whom she lost in early April" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMirror columnist Eva Simpson is looking at the toughest issues facing black people today in Britain as part of the Mirroraposs Black Britain campaign. Here, she explains why itaposs so important. Why in Britain, in , are black people still marching against racism and injustice  In a hard-hitting series, launching today on Windrush Day – the nd anniversary of the Empire Windrush arriving at Tilbury – we’ll look at issues affecting black British lives and why they matter. We start with health. I was honoured to play a role in commissioning a brilliant group of writers who are telling stories long overdue. I hope you read them in the spirit they are written in – a desire to deepen understanding of the issues and create a fairer society, where people are no longer judged by the colour of their skin, but by the content of their character. Mirror writer Adenike Adenitire takes a closer look at four of the most devastating health issues affecting Britainaposs black community. Here is what sheaposs found. Blood cancer  Orin Lewis OBE and we Beverley De-Gale OBE run the charity African Caribbean Leukaemia Trust. For  years it has worked to help patients with blood cancer and other illnesses to find stem cell, blood or organ donors, as there is an extreme shortage in the black community. ACLT was founded in  after the couple’s then six-year-old son Daniel De-Gale was diagnosed with leukaemia. He became the first black person in the UK to receive a stem cell transplant from an unrelated donor. Daniel unfortunately passed away in  at the age of  as a result of multiple organ failure. Orin says: “There is a pandemic virus called racism that is affecting all sectors of society, including health. The Royal College of Nursing came out last week to admit they’ve got a big problem with how black and other nurses from ethnic minorities are treated. “And we see it because our struggle to fund our work to save lives shouldn’t be this hard after nearly  years.”For details visit aclt.org.Sickle cell Sickle Cell Disease is Britain’s biggest genetic blood disease, affecting , people in the country – mainly those of African and Caribbean heritage. Episodes of excruciating pain may occur, which are treated with strong painkillers such as morphine. Those suffering from the condition are at risk of complications such as a stroke, blindness and bone damage. The disease can also result in deathnot treated properly. Approximately  babies are born with SCD in the UK every year but problems of lack of awareness and funding remain. John James OBE, CEO of Britain’s leading sickle cell charity The Sickle Cell Society, says: “Sickle Cell is something that has been known about for over  years but there has been very limited innovation research and development into modying treatment. Why is that  “Some people would ask: ‘If this was the biggest blood condition in the UK but it was affecting predominantly white people, would it still be the same ’” Dame Elizabeth Anionwu, who won a Letime Achievement Award at the Daily Mirror’s Pride of Britain Awards for transforming care for people with sickle cell disease, agrees that patients can face undue prejudice. She says: “There is still an issue about pain relief. “There are still some iniduals of African or Caribbean heritage, who are patients, but are thought of as drug addicts because they need drugs like morphine.”More information is avilable at sicklecellsociety.org.Mental health As a black person in the UK, you are four times more likely to be detained under the Mental Health Act than a white person, according to data collected from NHS Digital. Figures have shown black men are  times more likely to have serious mental health issues such as bipolar disorder and schizophrenia, yet only % of psychologists are from BAME backgrounds. An independent report conducted by the Centre for Mental Health noted that experiences of racism “appear to be a major influence on the mental health of black boys and young men that wear down their resilience during teenage and young adult years”. The study, which spoke to just under  participants, “found evidence of the incrementally damaging impact of a stream of negative media representations and demonising portrayals of black culture that led men to ‘mask’ their true selves”. Eche Egbuonu’s first experience with mental health issues was during his final year of university. The college lecturer, , from Hackney, East London, said: “There was an identity crisis I went through, where I was surrounded by lots of people but I still felt at my loneliest.” In , he suffered a psychotic episode of mania after having a dispute with his family. The police were called to the home and he was taken to a cell while a bed was prepared for him at a hospital. He says: “Some of the ways they got me into the cell seemed very heavy-handed given the fact that I had not been violent towards the officers or any other inidual. “So I could not understand that level of force or the need to place me in a prison cell.” Child birth  Black women in the UK are five times more likely than white women to die during childbirth according to a  report from Mothers and Babies Reducing Risk Through Audits and Confidential Enquiries. Candice Brathwaite, blogger and author of best-selling book I Am Not Your Baby Mother, understands this only too well after her own experience seven years ago of giving birth to her first child, daughter Esmé-Olivia. The  year-old says: “From beginning to end it was a mess. I was induced and left to wait hours for pain medicine while I was surrounded by labouring white women who seemed to be covered in this maternal care. It really felt like I was an annoyance.” After giving birth, Candice started feeling very unwell and told midwives. She says: “Their attitude was very much ‘you are overthinking it’ and ‘you are just having baby blues’.” But just two days after going home, baby Esmé fell asleep on Candice’s chest and the weight of her tiny body was enough to burst a septic sac growing underneath Candice’s C- section wound.

story: NewsHuge prehistoric circle of pits stuns scientists and could solve Stonehenge mysteryThe . mile-wide circle of deep pits was found less than two miles from Stonehenge in Wiltshire, and is believed to be the biggest prehistoric structure ever discovered in the UKShareCommentsByEstelle ShirbonDave Burke:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsIt is thought the centre of the circle could once have been a holy site " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA huge . mile-wide circle of deep pits has been discovered close to Stonehenge - and excited scientists believe it could finally help explain why the famous monument was built. The circle of shafts, believed to be , years old, is said to be the biggest prehistoric structure ever discovered in the UK. It was found just under two miles northeast of Stonehenge at Durrington in Wiltshire, and is thought to date back to the same period. It is not yet known what it is for - but it is possible the centre of the circle could have been a holy site.Prof Vincent Gaffney, one of the leading archaeologists, told: “This is an unprecedented find of major signicance within the UK.Key researchers on Stonehenge and its landscape have been taken aback by the scale of the structure and the fact that it hadn’t been discovered until now so close to Stonehenge.” And he continued: “I can’t emphasise enough the effort that would have gone in to digging such large shafts with tools of stone, wood and bone.” The newly-discovered settlement includes a henge, or circular structure, made of timber posts.  It could demonstrate that Neolithic people were able to count - as placing the shafts so precisely could only have been done by counting paces. So far  shafts have been found, each more than five metres deep and  metres in diametre. Archaeologist Nick Snashall, of the National Trust, said: As the place where the builders of Stonehenge lived and feasted, Durrington Walls is key to unlocking the story of the wider Stonehenge landscape. This astonishing discovery offers us new insights into the lives and beliefs of our Neolithic ancestors.The circle of pits is signicantly larger than any comparable prehistoric monument in Britain.

The haunting images show tables scattered with moulds of human jaws and sets of  teeth implants left strewn across the floor.The building opened as st Dental on Wetherby Road, Harrogate, in , specialising in dental moulds for dental prosthetics but also served as a private general dentist, as reported by Yorkshire Live.Before that, the site was occupied by Aesthetic Dental services. After st Dental was placed into administration in , it was bought out by investment firm Zeus Group, but the branch closed its doors in .Eight years later it remains unused and often attracts youngsters in the town who use it as a place to socialise. Previous attempts to takeover and refurbish the building have failed, with Starbucks submitting three planning applications to open a coffee shop at the address, only to see the plan rejected each time.The site was documented by an urban explorer who posts on Facebook as Lost Places  Forgotten Faces, sharing images and videos from within neglected locations around Yorkshire.  Posting more than  photos, the caption reads: st Dental was a Harrogate based private dental laboratory. Located within the town I live, Iaposve had this old dentist pinned since the beginning, and finally found out it had access. As evident throughout, the youth of Harrogate have used the building as a place to hang out. The building has been badly trashed and vandalised, with graffiti dating back to . Images from the outside show the building to be overgrown and the creepy interior to still have much of the abandoned equipment and documentation left in place. Tables are covered in dental implants to replace missing teeth, medical masks, surgical equipment, documentation, and patient records. Moulds for both inidual teeth and entire jaws have been left to gather dust, along with a cabinet containing drawers full of  teeth.

The first post chan containing the #BaldforBLM hashtag was made on Thursday, June  by an anonymous American user. The hashtag #BaldforBLM has since been used tens of thousands of times on Twitter, often by newly created accounts encouraging others to shave their heads. But soon after the campaign began and the hashtag began to trend, parts of the internet began to fight back. Twitter user @Lizzeth_Lemon responded to a popular tweet from a new account, claiming that it was using her photo. She tweeted: Hi yaposall, those pictures are of me. The K-Pop community - who love South Korean pop music - also started to fight back. They have a huge online presence and can use it to drown out other agendas as they have such a following.The K-Pop fans began to flood the #BaldforBLM hashtag with short, K-pop videos made by themselves to take over the hashtag and claim it for themselves.One K-Pop fan tweeted: Just found out about another fake hashtag: #BaldForBLM which is a Chan troll tag once again. story: NewsHorric search history of teen who killed himself as parents slam GoogleThe tragic case of Keelian Jensen who took his own le after viewing suicide content on Google and YouTube has echoes in the UK story of -year-old Molly Russell, who ended her le after viewing posts on InstagramShareByJoseph WilkesReporter:,  JUN News " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA mother whose son killed himself was horried to find his Google search history contained multiple sources detailing how to take his own le. Stina Jensen says she is appalled that such information was so easily available to her son Keelian, who took his own le at the age of  after reading several websites and a video on YouTube, the video sharing site owned by Google.Mrs Jensen, who was taken completely by surprise by the death of loving and gentle son, told News how internet search giant Google should be doing more to prevent people finding horrendous suicide material.She said: The night before he died, he started out searching very normal things. He was right into Xbox and he had searched when this new game was coming out. He searched the moon and stuff like that, very normal things. I clicked on what he had clicked on. I was shocked because I thought any child out there could do this. The search terms he typed in were very specic and should have raised red flags. The tragic story of Keelian, from Coominya in south east Queensland, has echoes in the UK case of Molly Russell, whose dad Ian Russell has campaigned for tech giants to take urgent steps to protect young people and stop hosting harmful content.Molly was just  when she killer herself just days before her th birthday in  after viewing suicide material on Instagram. Mr Russell, from Harrow, north London, who runs the Molly Rose Foundation in memory of his daughter, has urged: “For the safety of young people, the s need to do something quickly to make the internet safer.” He said last year: “It’s still all too easy to find such dangerous content.” He added: “In the hours between us saying ‘sleep well’ and the terrible dawning of next day, Molly’s only other influence must’ve come from beyond our house, beyond our love and protection - from the internet.”In May last year we reported how Health Secretary Matt Hancock met Facebook, Snapchat, Google and Instagram and they agreed to fund the Samaritans to help identy dangerous content and create a best practice guide to tackling it. The Government will appoint an independent regulator to hand out fines and hold tech bosses personally liable for harmful content. But legislation might take two years. Speaking alongside Mr Russell, Andy Burrows, associate head of child safety online with the NSPCC, said: “Until we have legislation passed the Government should monitor whether s are playing ball with this interim code of practice [and] name and shame those that drag their heels.”  In this latest case, Keelian had begun searching for information on how to take his own le at around am. He had struggled with mental health issues and his family said he wore his heart on his sleeve, was sensitive and affectionate, but appeared to be in a good place before his death last month. His death took everyone by surprise, with no warning signs.  When searching using the words Keelian did that morning, an ad for a free, -hour telephone crisis support service does appear. But Mrs Jensen says such sites which her son found - and any relating to self-harm - should be blocked to stall people in the depths of despair, and give them time to rethink, or give their loved ones a window of time in which to help them. She told News how it didnapost seem like her son had put much thought into what he was doing and his Google searches went from normal stuff straight to the suicide content.

story: NewsPanic after giant mushroom-shaped cloud fills sky in Ukraine close to ChernobylThe huge cloud was spotted in Kiev, Ukraine, just  miles away from Chernobyl, which was the site of the worlds worst nuclear disaster in , but officials told residents not to panicShareCommentsByGheorghi CaraseniJamie Hawkins:,  JUN NewsKiev was covered by an unusual cloud in the form of a nuclear mushroom, just  miles from Chernobyl " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailOfficials have told people not to panic after a city less than  miles from Chernobyl was covered in a giant mushroom-shaped cloud. Chernobyl, in Ukraine, was the site of the worldaposs worst nuclear disaster in  when a reactor meltdown caused a major radiation leak. But concerns were raised after the huge cloud was spotted in the capital Kiev.Some locals speculated that Russian president Vladimir Putin may have been testing nuclear weapons while others feared it could be aUFO .aposMaxim Volokhapos wrote: Is it Putin is testing a new nuclear weapon  And aposMariya Pulyakapos said: Is that a UFO   However, the mushroom shaped cloud is said to be a naturally-occurring weather phenomenon.Dramatic images show the startling cloud in the blue skies over Kiev. And the Ukrainian State Emergency Service later shared photos with the caption: Admit it, who got scared  According to the officials, there was no reason to panic as the unusual cloud is a rare phenomenon known as an anvil cloud so there was no reason for any worries. They added: We have had these types of clouds before above Kiev Oblast, Ternopil Oblast and Vinnitsa. An anvil cloud, also called cumulonimbus incus, is a cumulonimbus cloud which has reached stratospheric stability and has formed the characteristic flat, anvil-top shape. The clouds typically do not move, no matter how strong the wind is, and later slowly disappear. If often signies on oncoming thunderstorm. The official death toll for those killed after the Chernobyl disaster stands at just  - among them were  firefighters who died of Acute Radiation Syndrome, an agonising and gruesome way to die.  However, many believe the horrying true figure of those who lost their lives as a direct result is in the thousands. Many of those who died as a direct result of the incident on April , , were not killed as a result of the explosion and instead the devastating effects of radiation. The Union of Concerned Scientists estimates between , and , people died as a result of the disaster, whereas Greenpeace places the figure much higher at between , and ,.  Many people living hundreds of miles from the explosion site fell ill with illnesses in the aftermath of the disaster. People experienced everything from strange cancers, to birth deformities and other serious illnesses.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Evangelical groups have been giving a drug used for parasitic infections in animals to people living in the Amazon and passing it off as a vaccination against coronavirus.As the world races to find a vaccine, evangelic groups and a mayor in the region of Loreto, in north-eastern Peruaposs Amazon area, have been giving locals injections of ivermectin, which has not been proven to be effective and has terrible side effects. Spanish newspaper El Pais report up to , people in the town of Nauta have received the treatment with Leonardo Tello, the director of local radio station Radio Ucamara, telling reporters the side effects have been terrible. Tello said that since May, the mayor of the province and an Evangelic alliance have called citizens, using radio stations, to be vaccinated with ivermectin asit were a vaccine against coronavirus. In Nauta, at least , people have received it. He said that many of those who had received the treatment had suffered an increase in their heart rate whilst others have warned of diarrhoea as a side effect. Tello says that local Evangelical pastors have linked coronavirus with the devil and the end of the world, offering the injections as a salvation. Wadson Trujillo, the head of the indigenous community in Cuninico, said that volunteers from the Misiones Evangelicas de la Amazoniahad gone to the area to give injections of ivermectin to villagers, saying that it was a medicine passed by law that gives positive results as a vaccine. He said: Almost everybody here had coronavirus symptoms and they are fighting against it with homemade medicine. He said that seven of the  coronavirus tests carried out in the community had come back positive, saying that they now have face masks for the whole population. Local media reported that in the Peruvian Amazon, where around one million people live and around , people are indigenous, fear of coronavirus has seen the widespread use of traditional medicines which have not been proven effective against the virus.The General Management of Medicine of the Ministry of Health of Peru have already warned about the use of ivermectin saying that it has not yet met all the requirements for use on humans. The ministry said: Ivermectin for animals should not be used as a replacement for ivermectin for use on human beings in order to treat coronavirus.

title: blether elmwood juniors scotland tracksuits craig brewster
story: Lorraine Cormack requested a photo of her late dad in a football team.Lorraine, from Ambleside Avenue in Kirkton, Dundee, asked: “My dad David Lambird played for Lochee Harp JFC and ious other teams.“I’m not sure of the other teams’ names.“He worked with DC Thomson for  years in the pressroom as a gaffer.“Sadly, he died in January .“I would be really gratefulyou could find any photos of him.”I couldn’t find a Lambird playing for Harp, but the surname cropped up in this Elmwood JFC team photo from season -.Back row– Lambird, Gibson, Gilroy, Harrow, Johnstone, Walker. Front row – Fraser, Crighton, Burke, Lorimer, Grant.Jim Aberdein replied to his own contribution, which featured in our April  issue.Jim had told of the time his junior club Elmwood made the ultimate sacrice of folding, to allowThis, of course, also maintained The Shipbuilders’ claim of being the oldest continual junior football club in Scotland.Jim offered further information from that time, and said: “These were marvellous memories.“I also remember Gus Malone’s fatherwas on the committee of Elmwood at the time.“He was very instrumental in trying to re-form Elmwood JFC after we had taken over the East Craigie name.“When he first applied to the juniors for reinstatement, I am sure it was refused – for reasons which I can’t recall.“I remember he put a team of old and new Elmwood players together on the assumption that we would be back in the league.“He managed to procure a new set of stripsand we played a friendly at North End Park, losing -. That same night, the news came through that the reinstatement had been turned down.“I’m very happy to see that East Craigie are still firmly established in the Scottish Junior Football Association.“I am sure you will have some correspondence on the story and it will be interesting to see and read some of the views.“Keep up the good work.”Younger readers of this column may not remember a senior football competition called the Dewar Shield.This competition featured the County cup holders of Stirlingshire, Forfarshire, Aberdeenshire and Perthshire, and was the brainchild of then Lord Provost of Perth, Mr JA Dewar.It was first competed for in  and ran until .A quirky rule, certainly in the early years, was to pool all the drawings of the matches afterIt wasn’t competed for every year and, occasionally, one tournament would run over more than one season.Of the  competitions, Aberdeen won , while St Johnstone triumphed on eight occasions.Indeed, Saints were the last winners of the trophy.Continuing tales regarding football referees, it was reported in  that: “During the Berwick Rangers v Albion Rovers match, referee Bill Mullen sent a photographer packing when he joined in the players’ protests after a Berwick goal was disallowed”. vw, px"  East Fe East Fe players take a break from training during their promotion-winning season in -.Back row – Pat Quinn, Bertie Miller, John Bernard. Middle row – Johnny Love, Alex Jamieson, Colin McDonald, John Brown, Billy McPhee. Front row – Rab Cairns, Dave Gorman, Jim Finlayson, Brian McNicoll.Five Dundee-based players are in the photo – Jamieson, McDonald, Brown, Finlayson, McNicoll.First-team regulars of that stage of the season missing from the photo include Davie Clarke, Peter McQuade, John Martis, Walter Borthwick and Graeme Honeyman.This photo of the Scotland international team sees them, unusually, in green tracksuits.It was taken before the - draw with England at Wembley in .Back row– Unknown, Alex Hamilton, Bill Brown, Pat Crerand, Billy McNeill , John Greig, Eddie McCreadie. Front row – Ian St John, Willie Henderson, Bobby Collins, Billy Bremner, Denis Law, Davie Wilson.Bremner was the only player not to take part in the game.Robert Johnston saw the photo of the Scotland national team from season - in the March  issue of BwB.It was shown solely to highlight Tommy Docherty’s involvement as an international player.“That was a great photo,” said Robert, of Linlathen, Dundee.“With friends, I’ve been having a discussion regarding that team, and trying to get the names.“We are not sure of a few. Can you oblige by printing it again with all the names ”Glad to do so.Back row– Alex Parker, Eric Caldow, Ian McColl, Tommy Younger, Bobby Evans, Samuel Baird, D Walker . Front row – George Herd, Jimmy Murray, Tommy Docherty, John Mudie, Jim Forrest, Tommy Ewing.Well-known former Dundee junior player and official Alex Duncan recently relayed tales from his connections with Elmwood JFC.Alex also played for close rivals Stobswell and, indeed, co-managed them at one stage.He said: “I was co-manager of Stobswell along with Billy McGann, the former East Fe goalkeeper.“We had a pretty decent side and got better when we signed Craig Brewster as a youngster from Dundee United.“Craig did really well with us and it wasn’t long before senior clubs were looking at him again.“Doug Houston was manager of Forfar Athletic and he invited us to bring up the team for a“After the game, he signed Craig for a fee of £.“Instead of making out the cheque to the club, Billy suggested giving half to Craig, as he wasn’t getting a signing-on fee.“This was agreed . . . £ to Craig and £ to Stobbie.“However, when our secretary Angus Adam found out, he was furious.“So much so that he sacked Billy on the spot!“Angus asked me to take over, but I declined.”Football players, managers and staff are always sought for quotes by the media.I’m continuing to share some of them with you, which are associated with the ScotlandScotland midfielder Scott Brown, speaking in , said: “I think the whole country is sick of sitting at home watching everyone  play.“I was only  the last time Scotland made it to the World Cup Finals – France . It’s so long ago I can hardly remember it.”It’s now  years on, and still no sign of our luck changing! title: family lead tributes to prominent dundee business owner
story: Tribute has been paid to a former Lawside Academy pupil who became a prominent business owner in the city.Jacqui Croal, who worked behind the counter in the Dog Food Shop on Dock Street, Discovery Crafts and Needlework shop on Commercial Street and Mitchford Fashions on Blackness Road sadly passed away last week, aged  years.She worked alongside her husband, Fraser, in the pet food store for a number of years whilst branching out into other businesses.Her son, Mike Strachan, led the tributes today to his mother, who once appeared on an album cover for the esteemed Dundonian accordion player, Arthur Spink.Mike, , added: #Mum always had a decent head for business. The Dog Food Shop had been been in the family for decades.#The craft shop on Commercial Street was there for around - years and Mitchford Fashions was on Blackness Road in the late eighties.#As well as running a number of successful businesses she also ran a Super Slim club from the late seventies that was held in the RGR Hall in Lochee amongst other venues in Angus and Tayside.Mike recounts a moment when Academy Award winner, Jane Fonda personally wrote a letter to his mum regarding the classes.He added: #Mum ran a Jane Fonda workout and Jane actually got in contact with her to advise her to stop using her name as part of the classes.#Slimming clubs were massive at the time and despite the letter from Jane, the classes were hugely successful.#As well as working tirelessly in the local business community, the pensioner was also an accomplished pianist and also taught the piano to many people across Dundee.Mike added: #Mum had always been an extremely busy person. title: glamis castle gardens to reopen to public from june 29
story: Glamis Castle Gardens will reopen later this month.The gardens, which are a  minute drive from Dundee will re-open to the public from June .Plant lovers and families will be able to wander through the Italian Garden, walk through the Walled Garden which houses fruits and vegetables and take a stroll through the Macbeth Trail.Children can enjoy a grassed maze in the Walled Garden as well.Visitors can also take a picnic with them to enjoy in the gardens.Takeaway food will also be on offer.A one-way system has been put in place round the gardens as part of the new safety measures and hand sanitising facilities have been installed.All tickets must be booked in advance and can be booked online.Entry to the gardens is priced at £. for an adult, £ for a student or senior , £. for a childand £ for a family which includes two adults and a maximum of three children.The Castle is set to open on July  in accordance with government guidelines.For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite. title: letters to the editor may 15 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,A big thank you to whoever has tidied up Ardrishaig Community Garden, mown the grass and repaired and painted the fences.Such a peaceful place to call into while out exercising. I can#t wait for the day I can go back there to sit and contemplate, enjoy the views and read or paint.Cheryl Ratclfe-Nye, Ardrishaig.Sir,I would like to thank all the telecommunications workers in Scotland, many of whom have been designated key workers, for how they’ve responded to the coronavirus outbreak.They are providing essential support to the NHS and keeping all of us connected during this dficult time.From the engineers going out to keep our broadband and mobile networks connected, to the vital contact centre staff helping customers when they need it most, they deserve recognition.My colleagues, working with the Scottish Government and NHS, worked quickly to provide the temporary NHS Louisa Jordan hospital in Glasgow with communications. They are doing the same to support other temporary NHS services across Scotland.Our people have worked around the clock with health boards across the country to offer new, technical solutions to help frontline health workers get on with their jobs during this crisis.Our frontline staff in contact centres across Scotland – including Aberdeen, Dundee, Glasgow and Greenock – have risen to this unprecedented challenge. We’ve received a huge surge of customers asking for faster connections to help with home working, home schooling and running their businesses remotely.These colleagues – most of whom can now work from home when they want to – have performed a critical role keeping our customers, including frontline health workers and vulnerable people, connected.The people in our two  contact centres in Scotland are also playing a critical role, answering lesaving emergency calls.I couldn’t be more proud of how my colleagues have responded to these challenges and their desire to help us all through this crisis.Jane Wood, BT Group director in Scotland, Edinburgh.COVID- is seriously not a jokeGlobally kills thousands of folkYou start coughing, you can#t breatheWithout a respirator, this earth you#ll leaveSocial distancing is now in placeKeep two metres apart, not face to faceWash your hands frequently and well hours on surfaces it can dwellShop infrequently, for essentials onlyDon#t mix with othersyou#re lonelyKeep in touch by text and phoneDon#t put yourself at risk, stay aloneIt#s hoped soon this contagion will peakThen we canto normal, so to speakDon#t travel to other towns by carIt can spread the virus near and farSports, socialising and most work on holdThe alternative could cause damage untoldSupport the NHS, essential workers and neighboursThen we#ll defeat this virus by all our laboursDugald MacGilp, Lochgilphead.Sir,We are looking for people who have the passion to bring communities together, believe in the power of co-operation and who hold the well-being of their community at the forefront of their mind.The successful #Member Pioneers# will receive full training and business support as they help groups and iniduals during the coronavirus pandemic and beyond. The pioneers will cover three wide areas: one based around Longrow in Campbeltown, another around The Avenue in Inveraray and a third around Bishopton Road, Lochgilphead.The new positions form part of a drive to recruit , pioneers across the country. Existing pioneers are currently involved in a wide range of activities including co-ordinating food drives and offering personal support to those unable to leave their homes.This has never been more important than now.The local area has so many strengths and we want to help communities be as resilient as possible against the new challenges posed by COVID-. The new pioneers will spearhead our efforts, support great causes and think up new ideas.To apply to be a Member Pioneer, visit jobs.coop member-pioneers. Roles are  hours a month. Closing date for both positions is Wednesday May .Russell Gill, head of co-operative and local engagement at Co-op.

title: letters to the editor may 22 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,Mental Health Awareness Week, now in its th year, runs from May  to May .This year, the theme for the week is kindness and across the country, people will be celebrating kindness in digital and creative ways within social distancing restrictions.The last couple of months, with all the uncertainty of the virus and the impact of lockdown, have been an extremely stressful and worrying time for many people across the Highlands and Islands. People who may have previously felt isolated in remote and rural communities may be feeling this even more acutely at this time, so it’s important they know support is available.Across the region, many people have also sadly faced the pain of losing loved ones to the virus or have fallen ill themselves, while others have seen their livelihoods put at risk or incomes reduced. All of this has put additional strain on people’s mental well-being.This year’s Mental Health Awareness Week is putting the focus on kindness as a means of helping people through the pandemic and building a better society as we emerge from it. We see many acts of kindness in the Highlands and Islands all the time, but this week is an opportunity for people to reflect on their interactions with others and how they can try and be a little kinder during this unprecedented time.David Stewart, MSP for Highlands and Islands region.Sir,During Mental Health Awareness Week, sight loss charity RNIB Scotland is highlighting the emotional reassurance and practical help it is offering during the coronavirus lockdown.Our Need to Talk telephone counselling service remains available in Argyll and Bute for anyone diagnosed with sight loss, as well as their families, friends and carers.Losing some or even all your sight can be devastating news to take in, but our trained helpers can support you in coming to terms with your condition and finding the way forward.RNIB is concerned the lockdown might be affecting people who are blind and partially sighted, many of whom are older, particularly hard. The uncertainty over access to basic shopping and medication, to information in accessible formats, the social isolation and barriers to being guided because of social distancing can all add and compound to the mental and emotional stress people are experiencing.As well as our Need to Talk service, the RNIB helpline on    is available for anyone with sight loss and we continue to organise social activities over the phone and social media.We want people with sight loss to know they are not alone and that help is available.James Adams, RNIB Scotland director, Edinburgh.The Scottish Invasive Species Initiativehas launched Alien Detectives – a fun and educational online resource to help the young and not so young  learn more about alien # or non-native – invasive species.Originally designed as a school education pack, the huge array of activities now includes a wide range of fun games and activities that anyone can enjoy at home, in the garden or on local walks during lockdown.Alien Detectives includes crafts, quizzes, worksheets, presentations and puzzles all themed around invasive species and the river environment. Although primarily aimed at young people, anyone with an interest in the environment or invasive species can enjoy them too.Our project team has been busy while homeworking during lockdown to produce these fantastic resources. We hope becoming Alien Detectives will bring many hours of enjoyment to iniduals and families during lockdown, especially at a time when most young people are not in a regular school environment and might be looking for a new challenge or activities to continue their learning.Invasive non-native species might be a new topic to many but it is a really important one. Invasive species can have a major impact on our environment and native wildle and are responsible for signicant bioersity loss in Scotland and across the world. We hope these resources will help raise awareness of the impacts of invasive species and inspire more young people to learn something about them.No prior knowledge is needed and there’s lots to learn and have fun with so become an Alien Detective and help us tackle invasive species today.All of the ‘Alien Detectives’ resources can be found at www.invasivespecies.scot alien-detectives.Callum Sinclair, SISI Project Manager, Newton Stewart.Sir,We may not be able to hold picnics in the usual way just yet, but why not hold the next best thing – a virtual picnic  That way you can invite as many people as you want.National charity Family Action is running its Virtual Family Picnic from May  to May  and everyone is invited. The charity has created a free pack full of tips, ideas and videos to help people host their own virtual picnic.You can hold your picnic in your garden, on your balcony or on the living room floor. Just find some space, make some tasty treats and connect with friends and family online.Although we are all still respecting social distancing and cannot meet in groups, we can still share experiences together and create happy memories.  And when lockdown finally ends we can do it all again, but this time in person.To find out more and to get your free pack, visit the Family Action website.David Holmes CBE, Family Action Chief Executive Officer, London

title: memories of tarbert herring and almost moving to loch fyne side
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsIn this time of lockdown, I am reminiscing on great times had in Argyll.I first visited Kintyre with my parents as a -year-old, my family having bought a mini car in . We stayed with Margaret and Iain McDonald at their home named Meadowview in Tarbert which was located near the school.We all enjoyed the area so much that we continued to visit every year for the next consecutive eight years.Margaret invited me to go out on the herring boats once or twice. One was named Village Maid and the other Village Belle and, needless to say, we often had kippers for breakfast, which were very nice. I remember there was a boat called the Southern Cross tied up to Cock Island # can anyone tell me any history of it and when it disappeared There also used to be a smokehouse for kippers along from Tarbert to Ardrishaig.Another fond memory I have is watching the logging trucks unloading on the quay and watching them get loaded on to large boats and I think then being shipped round to Sweden or Finland. Is that correct or not as I thought there was a paper mill at Fort William As mentioned earlier, I joined North West Ambulance Service in the s and Margaret used to send me the Argyllshire Advertiser and in one of them was an advert for recruitment to the Scottish Ambulance Service.I duly got an application form from Paisley and was all but sending the form in when I realised it would be very unfair to move so far away from our young children#s grandparents and for them to be unable to see them growing up. At the time your local pharmacist was retiring and my we Sue was a qualied pharmacist, but our children were both under school age so relied on her parents for child care. Ironically, I believe the job was filled with a Blackpool pharmacist whom I had met ocassionally.My love for Scotland continued, and we had our honeymoon travelling around Scotland and calling in at Tarbert for several days on the trip round.Our last trip up there was  in June as a treat from our daughter who accompanied us on this trip. The weather was glorious, and one day we caught the bus to Skipness and walked part of the Kintyre Way back.Another day we took the MacBrayne Ferry to Islay, which was again a glorious day out, also visited Crinan, Lochgilphead and Inveraray, followed by a couple of days fishing off the pier in Tarbert. We travelled back via Portavadie and Dunoon, and have in the past used the ferry to Arran, then Brodick, Ardrossan and home.Thank you for taking the time to read this. It has been good to share some of the memories of Argyll with you.#

story: Fiona ScottUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsFollowing the expected cancellation of shinty’s  cup competitions, the Camanachd Association has confirmed with title sponsor Tulloch Homes and Kingussie Camanachd Club that the plan to host the final in Kingussie will be postponed for a year and will now take place on September  .The Tulloch Homes Camanachd Cup Final willto the Highland venue for the first time since  and for its th anniversary.First contested in , the final of shinty’s national knock-out cup competition promises to be a brilliant day out for all the family and a  chance to watch two of the country’s elite shinty teams.Hundreds of tickets have already been sold and to be part of this historic moment you can secure your tickets, including some exclusive offers, on shinty.The  final takes place at The Dell and will be one of the biggest stagings of the event in its -year history with live traditional music, entertainment and a dedicated Kids Zone adding to the festival feel.The first final of the Camanachd Cup took place at Inverness on April  . Great interest was centred on the match, played at Needlefield, a piece of ground situated between Longman Road and Cromwell#s Fort, which was described as being #in good condition for the game#.The contending teams were Kingussie and Glasgow Cowal, two brilliant exponents of the game. The day was practically observed as a holiday in Kingussie and the special train which conveyed the team to Inverness brought more than  people to see the contest. From strath and glen, ardent enthusiasts are said to have flocked into the city, the streets of which contained wearers of kilt and knickerbocker galore.Entrance was a shilling and there were around , present. Gate receipts amounted to £. As the teams lined up on the field, the crowd anxiously weighed up their physical abilities.At the end of the day, Kingussie emerged victorious winning the championship by two hails # as they were then described # to Cowal’s .News of the victory of the home team was received with much satisfaction in Kingussie and district and the players were accorded an ovation on their , met by pipers and others carrying lighten torches, assembling at the station, and marching through the town, while bonfires were lit above the burgh and two on the farm of Dunachton.Gates for next year#s final will open at am on the day with the rising stars of shinty contesting the MacMaster Cup U final before the throw-up for the main event in the afternoon.The Tulloch Homes Camanachd Cup Final attracts thousands of spectators on the day and is also broadcast live by BBC Scotland across television, radio and online s.To buy your ticket contact your local club or buy online via www.shinty. title: letters to the editor june 5 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,Thank you for publishing the informative article in your May  edition about the ongoing consultation for the old Kilmartin church building, which runs to June .We would like to remind readers, particularly those who live in Slockavullin, Ford, Bridgend and Kilmichael Glassary and all the homes in between, that the consultation is for everyone who lives in the Dunadd area.So please share your views # http:dunadd.scot church  and then click #Register Your Opinion#.Gary Linstead, Dunadd Community Enterprise.Sir,Scotland#s Charity Air Ambulancemarked its seventh anniversary on May .I look back with pride and gratitude on a service that has saved and improved thousands of lives and on the organisations, communities, businesses and iniduals across Scotland who helped launch and sustain that service.None of us could have foreseen the situation we find ourselves in, as we reach this landmark seventh birthday. This is a challenging operational environment for our aircrew and an extremely dficult period for our fundraising teams as the restrictions are preventing all the events, talks and activities taking place which are so essential to help support the country#s only charity-funded helicopter air ambulance service.It costs around £ million each year to fund our Perth and Aberdeen-based helicopter air ambulances. Every penny needed to keep these two lesavers in the air seven days a week,  days a year, is donated by the people of Scotland. We receive no statutory government funding.Yet, as I reflect on how the Scottish public has risen to every request we have made of them over the past seven years, I feel confident they will not abandon #The People#s Helicopter# at this particular time of need.Please support SCAAyou can and help us celebrate the seventh anniversary of this lesaving service # your service.John Bullough, Chairman, Scotland#s Charity Air Ambulance, Perth Airport.Sir,Volunteers are always important. But in challenging times, when our communities need them most, they are invaluable.During Volunteers# Week # June  to June  # I am so proud of the Scout volunteers in Scotland. Together they are helping tens of thousands of young people gain skills for le # helping them speak up, play their part and find their place in the world.To keep everyone safe, Scouts aren#t able to meet face to face. But this hasn#t stopped our volunteers from supporting young people. So many of our brilliant leaders are still running meetings online, helping Scouts catch up with their friends and continue to earn their awards.At a time when our children#s lives are so badly disrupted, these sessions are providing a sense of normality and continuity that#s so important for their well-being. We have also been supporting families across Scotland and beyond with free resources at scouts.org.uk the-great-indoors.I#d like to say a huge thank you to all our volunteers, whether you drive the minibus, make the drinks, look after the accounts or help deliver vital skills for le. We couldn’t do it without you. Your kindness and resilience in these tough times is inspiring and is making a dference.Andrew Sharkey, chief commissioner, Scouts ScotlandAlison Macdonald replied: #Lockdown has made me realise I took the little things for granted, being able to visit family and friends whenever I like, going out for lunch, celebrating occasions and just being able to go for a drive because I can. But seeing how our wee community comes together in times of need is always inspiring. Everything from businesses volunteers adapting to supply frontline workers with much-needed supplies, to people volunteering to collect shopping and essentials for people shielding. It#s made me realise community spirit is still very much alive in Lochgilphead and all over Mid Argyll.#Belinda Braithwaite posted: #That I can find joy in small things such as the birds and connections with friends and the community. And that nature didn’t know we were in lockdown and spring sprung into le.#Duncan Black said: #What it#s made me realise is just how many people evidently long to be in Stasi-esque organisations and just how easily tyranny can be implemented under the excuse of fear or political pandering.#Fyonna Doe responded: #Not to take anything for granted, especially seeing my family and friends, going for lunches, getting my hair done # everyday things that were the norm until the lockdown.#Niamh Rodden posted: #To not take anyone or anything for granted, especially seeing family and friends. It never seemed like a big deal till now when you aren#t able to do so, especially when you have small children and grandparents are missing out on so much. But we are all keeping each other safe. Stay home unless it#s completely necessary, stay safe and hopefully the day we get to see family again won’t be far away.#Karen Pickering said: #That people do care. I never realised how much I took seeing family and friends for granted until now.#Morag Macdonald replied: #My home is my safe place and I would be in a mess without the care of my husband. How much I miss my family and how I need to hug them.#Cathie Wilson responded: #I miss my family and I can honestly put up with hubbys weird singing noises!#

title: mid argyll youth footballers show promise in strong league
story: Bruce WestUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThis was the Lochgilphead youngsters# fourth season playing -aside football.After two seasons in the Dumbarton League, finishing second then first in the league and winning the league cup both years, the boys moved to the Glasgow League in - finishing in the top half of a very competitive Division A and making it to the final of the league cup.Another competitive season was anticipated with five new teams joining the A Division.The season started well, with Star winning all three of their league cup group games against Cambuslang Reds, Cumbernauld Colts and Glasgow Red Star -, - and -.With Cambuslang Reds and Cumbernauld Colts being new opponents this was a good start and Star qualied for the knockout stages. But the COVID- lockdown interrupted proceedings.This season’s Scottish Cup was a bit of a disappointment with Star exiting the competition in the second round after losing out to a vastly improved Dumbarton United side -. On the plus side, the first round saw Star take on Paisley League team Pollok FC and an excellent performance saw Star run out convincing winners -, one of only four defeats suffered by Pollok in all competitions.In the West Region Cup, Star progressed to the quarter-final again. A first round bye, a convincing - win against Cambuslang FA then a walkover saw the Lochgilphead youths face Paisley League A Division team Erskine.In a hard-fought encounter, Star matched Erskine for most of the game but with only  players available they couldn’t get the breakthrough they needed and eventually lost -.Star started their league campaign in September with a competitive match against new team Thorn, who transferred from Paisley A Division. Star lost -.Two strong performances in October saw Star record  a terric - win over Shettleston, last season’s league runners up, and a - win against St Patrick’s Sports Academy # an entertaining but nerve-wracking game.A mid-season stutter in November saw the Lochgilphead boys lose out to Cathcart -, then Clydebank -, both newcomers.The losing run continued into early December as Star faced last season’s champions Drumchapel Amateurs ending up down - at half-time before recovering their form with a committed second half display to pull it back to -. Unfortunately they lost out to a fourth Drumchapel goal as they chased the winner themselves.This set Star back on track as they finished the year with a hugely convincing performance, demolishing Cathcart -.January and February proved a real battle with the weather with wind, rain and freezing temperatures # often all three # only allowing four games to take place. Star secured fine victories over Busby, -, and Glasgow Red Star, -, and fought back to grind out creditable draws with Shettleston, -, and Place Park, another new team, -.Star played one league game in March before lockdown and again it was another entertaining game with a rollercoaster feel to it. Facing up to Drumchapel Amateurs, both teams played out another terric match which had everything.Coming back from a goal down and with only  men, Star played cracking football to race into a - lead but it took its toll as Drumchapel stuck to their task to draw level before adding a couple more goals to secure a win in the final five minutes.This was another fine season for Red Star s, competing well in a strong league, with only  signed players.Though the season was cut short, the boys played  games winning , drawing two and losing seven. They scored  goals and conceded  goals. There were some cracking games and the boys were looking forward to the knock-out stages of the league cup.Inconsistency probably cost Star a few more wins, but that’s what youth football development is all about and there is potential for the boys to develop.Well done from coaches and parents to the  boys who played this season – Craig Aitken, Zak Barclay, Gregor Brown, Keiran Caskie, Lewis Curran, Ruaridh Green, Woody Hoad, Alexander McLean, Conner McMurchy, Leon Murphy, Innes Paterson, Jamie Stewart and Tom West.Thanks for great support goes to sponsors Ardrishaig Community Trust, main strip, SC Crawford Building Contractors Limited, change strip and zip tops, Jewsons, tracksuits, and Mid Argyll Youth Development Services and the parents, supporters, referees and opposition teams that have made the season so enjoyable.
