But we hope to keep the resilience team mothballed, as it were, for future use, having set it up and had volunteers happy to have their names kept on a list.In the meantime, information relating to the coronavirus can be found at www.tyninghamevillagehall.org.uk or by going to www.eastlinton.ukPeople can also contact   or  .HaddingtonTHINGS are getting much quieter in Haddington, though calls are still coming in, while the number of resilience team volunteers is shrinking, says Haddington Community Council vicechairman Chris McEwan.Emergency shopping has been completed for some residents, and the team has seen several more foodbank referrals, as workplaces remain closed and employees are struggling financially.The team is also continuing to perform prescription uplts for those who remain shielding.ldquoItrsquos becoming more dficult for us, as some of our volunteers are starting toto work themselves, said Chris.The resilience teamrsquos pool of volunteers is now ldquoseverely diminished, said Chris.ldquoWe had -odd volunteers and wersquore now a fraction of that.While referrals from the council have slowed down, the group continues to support residents with whom it has struck up a relationship, and who remain in need of assistance.The community council team is discussing when to wind down support.ldquoItrsquos all based on what the Scottish Governmentrsquos shielding targets are, said Chris.ldquoWersquore hoping East Lothian Council has a plan for this. The biggest problem we have now is the number of volunteers.Chris also pointed out the impact all the work during lockdown has had on the volunteers themselves.ldquoWersquove all been doing this since March, he said, ldquoa lot of us havenrsquot had a break since then, so therersquos that aspect ndash we need to keep the mental health of our volunteers up. My bad jokes are usually the biggest source of enjoyment!Anyone needing assistance can still visit www.haddingtoncc.org.uk or call   between am and pm.GfordTHE Gford Larder launched this week, to help support households in the community council area who are having dficulties accessing essential food and household items due to the financial impact of Covid-.The larder will operate by appointment only on Tuesdays and Fridays in Gford Village Hallrsquos Todrick Room.The appointments system will allow organisers to manage social distancing and numbers, as well as give people the privacy to attend in confidence.Adam White, Gfordrsquos resilience co-ordinator, said: ldquoWe were very kindly offered a private financial donation to establish a service for people living within our community council area.ldquoFirst we spent time researching similar schemes, most notably in Dirleton, to shape our thinking. It is important that whatever we do is of real help to people, is safe and is sustainable.ldquoWersquore very grateful to everyone who has helped us reach this stage, to our coordinators Julia and Katy, and our volunteers who will be operating the larder. We will be gathering feedback on the Gford Larder as it progresses.Organisers welcome support for the new service but are asking people not to donate food.They said: ldquoWe are not accepting food donations. This is because it adds another complex layer of organisation that would need to be managed ndash it is harder to offer certainty of what people using the service can expect to find and it is harder to manage stock control ndash we want to avoid waste.ldquoIt also means our co-ordinators can respond to what visitors are telling us they would benefit from. We have carried out research before making this decision and we hope you understand.Instead, people wanting to donate food are asked to consider East Lothian Foodbank, in Tranent, with Yester Church in the process of setting up a collection point.Gford Community Councilrsquos Facebook and website pages have been updated to include information on the new larder service, posters are being created and leaflets will be delivered to all homes in the area.To find out more, go to www.gfordvillage.org post the-gford-food-larderMeanwhile, additional supplies of face coverings have been handed into Hoggrsquos newsagent by local volunteers and crafters who have been busy sewing.All donations are used by the ldquoSoup and a Smile service volunteers, and the face coverings have been very well received by members of the community.Anyone who needs support or wants to help can contact: Jo Allen, on   or chairgfordcc@gmail Adam White, on   or adamjswhite@outlook Wendy Ferguson, on   or wendyferguson.wf@gmail or the Rev Aniko Schuetz Bradwell, on   or anikoschuetzbradwell@churchofscotland.org.uk

title: couples-living-apart-scotland-can-sleepover-today----rules
story: As part of the countryrsquos move into Phase  in the route map out of lockdown, Nicola Sturgeon announced plans for an lsquoextended householdrsquo.She said the Scottish Government was mindful of the ldquowider harms that come from the restrictions put in place to tackle the coronavirus ndash including ldquoloneliness and isolation, particular for older people living alone and lone parents.And while the idea of an extended household has wide-ranging benefits, therersquos one aspect in particular, called by some as a ldquosex bubble, that has people talking.The new arrangements, permitted from today, means that non-cohabiting couples - where at least one of them lives alone - can be reunited indoors without social distancing for the first time in three months."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Scotland enters Phase  of lockdown, Nicola Sturgeon confirms","description": "Lockdown restrictions are being eased further in Scotland, with people who live on their own or only with children under  able to form an  ucextended household group ud from Friday, Nicola Sturgeon has said.","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media MlYzw poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests MlYzw.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.eastlothiancourier video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "East Lothian Courier","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.eastlothiancourier sitelogo ","width": ,"height": What can I do under an lsquoextended household rsquoWithin an extended household group, people will be able to meet indoors, without physical distancing and stay overnight - though onlythey wish.But they must continue to see any other households outdoors only, and stay more than  metres apart from them.Who can form one Only people who live alone, or who live only with children under -years-old, can form an extended household.The idea is it could allow, for example, a grandparent who lives on their own to form a group with another household in their family.It will allow a single parent and their children to join with another household for support.And, of course, couple who live apartcan be reunited and stay over.But, an important detail to note: people who are shielding CANNOT form an extended household.Can I have more than one extension No. A person should not form an extended household with more than one other household.Can I leave my lsquobubblersquo Yes, you can.Households can agree to end the arrangement at any time ndash but they should NOT then form a subsequent lsquobubblersquo with another household. So perhaps choose wisely.Whatsomeone in my lsquoextended householdrsquo gets coronavirus This is where it gets tricky.Put simply,one member of your extended household gets the virus, the entire group has to isolate.This is regardless of whether or not they are living in the same property.As an addition to that, Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoI would also encourage those who choose to form extended households to pay particular attention to hygiene measures ndash to reduce the risk that one household will bring the virus into another.When will this be extended to other groups of people The First Minister did not provide a date on when this could be extended to more people.But she added she will ldquoconsiderand to what extent we can expand it over the next few weeks, admitting it will not immediately make a dference to everyone.She urged the public to visit the Scottish Government website for more information, adding: ldquoWith the best will in the world, we cannot provide precise answers for every bespoke situation.ldquoSo when in doubt, use your judgement and err on the side of caution.

title: racing-gets-green-light-return
story: Musselburgh Racecourse will stage the first of five meeting on the last day of the month with fixtures also planned for Wednesday, July .They will be followed by fixtures scheduled on Friday, July , Thursday, July , and Wednesday, August .The first race in Scotland since the Covid outbreaktakes place at Ayr this Monday .It is expected other fixtures will be assigned by the British Horseracing Authority in due course to Musselburgh and Scotlandrsquos other four racecourses.Musselburghrsquos management team hasestablished procedures for hosting controlled meetings without spectators which meet the highest health and safety and bio-security standards and have been working closely with East Lothian Council and Police Scotland in preparation for the resumption of racing.Bill Farnsworth, Musselburgh Racecourse general manager, welcomed the announcement and said Scottish racing was fully prepared to play a vital role in supporting owners, trainers and the wider horseracing sector.He said: ldquoControlled horseracing meetings have been very successfully introduced in England, Ireland and a number of other countries and we are looking forward to playing our part in getting the wheels of the industry turning again in Scotland.Racing fans will be able to follow the action through a number of dferent options, including live screening on Racing TV, ITV Racing, on catch up via Racing TV Player, and through bookmakers websites for those who have accounts.Joe FitzPatrickMSP, minister for public health,sport  wellbeing, said: ldquoIrsquom sure that this news will be welcomed by racing fans across the country. The resumption of professional sports is another step towards some level of normality and its safe resumption is only possible thanks to a constructive relationship between the Scottish Government and bodies like Scottish Racing.Delly Innes, manager of Scottish Racing, said: ldquoWe are delighted to welcome theof racing in Scotland after a long, but necessary, absence as Scotland faced the challenges of Covid-. This has been an immensely challenging time for our five excellent racecourses, but this is an important first step on the road to recovery, and we will be working hard to ensure all our participants are familiar with, and adhere to Scottish rules and guidance where these dfer from UK guidance.ldquoWe are raring to go with an exciting programme of fixtures in the months ahead which will help support the wider Scottish and British racing industry, and provide entertainment to viewers across the country.

title: lifeboat-called-assist-kayaker-distress
story: The crew was paged at .am by the Coastguard after the kayaker had fallen into the water while fishing half a mile off shore.The all weather leboat was launched from nearby Torness Power Station at .am.Two crew members were on board and set off to try and locate the man.They received help from a passing angler who had spotted him clinging to his boat, they then rescued the man and helped him aboard the leboat.The crew ed to the shore and helped the man reach coastguard teams from Dunbar and North Berwick.The man was said to be extremely cold and shivery and was then assessed by paramedics, he appeared to otherwise be uninjured.The leboat crew then helped recover the manrsquos kayak and at am were stood down by the Coastguard.A Dunbar RNLI spokesman said: ldquoAlthough the kayaker was well-equipped he had been in the water for sometime and was initially reluctant to call for help. We would urge anyone in dficulty in or near the water to call  and ask for the Coastguard.As Scotland moves into phase two of easing lockdown restrictions, Dunbar RNLI urged that boat users be prepared before ing to the water.As boats have been sitting idle for the past few months people are asked to make sure they have good, fresh fuel in the tank and that water and oil are at the correct levels.People are asked to check weather forecasts and sea conditions before setting off and to always wear a lejacket, should a person fall into the water unexpectedly they are four times more likely to survivewearing one.They are also asked to carry a means to call for help and to not put themselves, their family or the emergency services at risk.

title: far-can-travel-scotlands-phase-2-can-drive-england
story: Early on in her briefing, Nicola Sturgeon said that as part of the ldquostaged approach, the Scottish Government guidance will continue to be asking people to ldquoas far as possible to stay within or close to their local area.She added that their ambition ldquois to be in a position to lt this in Phase  and in time for the proposed resumption of tourism from July .How far can I travel At this stage for leisure and recreation purposes, Ms Sturgeon says people should ldquonot travel more than five miles or so from their home.She added: ldquoOutdoor businesses, such as zoos and garden attractions, can also reopen from June  ndash although people should not be travelling more than five miles to visit them and tickets should be bought in advance.The retail sector is also set to open on June .However she added that, as revealed previously, the five-mile limitdoes NOT apply to meeting family and friends.These meetings should take place outdoors, but under new Phase  measures you can go inside to use the toilet.Can I travel to England A Scottish Government spokesperson says that as long as you can get there and back in one day, you can visit family in England.They told the Scotsman that it would be fine to travel to, for example, Carlisle or Berwick, to visit family ndash so long as you do not have to stay overnight.The spokesman did however advise against travelling too far, adding it would become more dficult to make it back in one day ndash urging people to ldquoexercise common sense in their actions.Can I use public transport Public transport is continuing to operate at a massively reduced capacity to allow for physical distancing.But under Phase , there will be a slight increase in services ndash but with new rules.From today, face coverings are mandatory on all public transport in Scotland, with customers urged to avoid peak times wherever possible to allow for key workers to use the services.

title: 1-650-spent-remind-residents-keep-distance
story: The ft-high information boards have been produced to remind people to follow social distancing rules as restrictions on outdoor gatherings are eased.With the message Keep East Lothian Moving, the boards remind people to maintain a two-metre distance and "consider others when youre out and about".The messages are accompanied by images of people out walking their dogs, with their families, running and cycling and an elderly person using a walking aid, as well as a skateboarder.East Lothian Council said it had invested more than pound, in the boards which will appear across  key sites.The move comes as the local authority also deployed mobile electronic signs on the A coast road over the weekend reminding people to stay local.The electronic signs, usually used to deter speeding on the road, changed its message as the council reopened its larger coastal car parks for local residents to use.They warned people not to stray too far from their home comforts with the message, Stay Local No Public Toilets.A council spokesperson said the new social distance boards would be placed at sites around the county.They said: ldquoAt this stage, we have identied  locations in dferent parts of East Lothian where these materials, highlighting the importance of physical distancing guidelines, will be put in place."Thirty copies have been ordered at a cost of pound,.

title: losing-sense-smell-coronavirus---happens
story: FROM the first reports coming out of Wuhan, Iran and later Italy, we knew that losing your sense of smellwas a signicant symptom of the disease.Now, after months of reports, both anecdotal and more rigorous clinical findings, we think we have a model for how this virus may cause smell loss.One of the most common causes of smell loss is a viral infection, such as the common cold, sinus or other upper respiratory tract infections.Those coronaviruses that donrsquot cause deadly diseases, such as COVID-, Sars and Mers, are one of the causes of the common cold and have been known to cause smell loss.In most of these cases, sense of smell s when symptoms clear, as smell loss is simply the result of a blocked nose, which prevents aroma molecules reaching olfactory receptors in the nose. In some cases, smell loss can persist for months and years.For the novel coronavirus , however, the pattern of smell loss is dferent. Many people with COVID- reported a sudden loss of sense of smell and then a sudden and fullto a normal sense of smell in a week or two.Interestingly, many of these people said their nose was clear, so smell loss cannot be attributed to a blocked nose.For others, smell loss was prolonged and several weeks later they still had no sense of smell. Any theory of anosmia in COVID- has to account for both of these patterns.This suddenof a normal sense of smell suggests an obstructive smell loss in which the aroma molecules cannot reach the receptors in the nose .Now that we have CT scans of the noses and sinuses of people with COVID- smell loss, we can see that the part of the nose that does the smelling, the olfactory cleft, is blocked with swollen soft tissue and mucus ndash known as a cleft syndrome.The rest of the nose and sinuses look normal and patients have no problem breathing through their nose.We know that the way SARS-CoV- infects the body is by attaching to ACE receptors on the surface of cells that line the upper respiratory tract.A protein called TMPRSS then helps the virus invade the cell. Once inside the cell, the virus can replicate, triggering the immune systemrsquos inflammatory response. This is the starting point for the havoc and destruction that this virus causes once in the body.Initially, we thought that the virus might be infecting and destroying the olfactory neurons.These are the cells that transmit the signal from the aroma molecule in your nose to the area in the brain where these signals get interpreted as ldquosmell.However, an international collaboration showed recently that the ACE proteins the virus needs to invade the cells were not found on the olfactory neurons.But they were found on cells called ldquosustentacular cells, which support the olfactory neurons.We expect that these support cells are likely to be the ones that are damaged by the virus, and the immune response would cause swelling of the area but leave the olfactory neurons intact.When the immune system has dealt with the virus, the swelling subsides and the aroma molecules have a clear route to their undamaged receptors and the sense of smell s to normal.So why does smell notin some cases This is more theoretical but follows from what we know about inflammation in other systems.Inflammation is the bodyrsquos response to damage and results in the release of chemicals that destroy the tissues involved.When this inflammation is severe, other nearby cells start to be damaged or destroyed by this ldquosplash damage. We believe that accounts for the second stage, where the olfactory neurons are damaged.Recovery of smell is much slower because the olfactory neurons need time to regenerate from the supply of stem cells within the lining of the nose.Initial recovery is often associated with distortion of the sense of smell known as parosmia, where things donrsquot smell like they used to.For many parosmics, for instance, the smell of coffee is often described as burnt, chemical, dirty and reminiscent of sewage.Physiotherapy for the noseOlfaction has been called the Cinderella of the senses because of its neglect by scientic research.But it has come to the forefront in this pandemic. The silver lining is that we will learn a lot about how viruses are involved in smell loss from this. But what hope is there for people with a loss of smell now The good news is that the olfactory neurons can regenerate. Theyrsquore regrowing in almost all of us, all of the time. We can harness that regeneration and guide it with ldquophysiotherapy for the nose: smell training.

title: new-bbc-documentary-series-jamie-genevieve-great-indoors-air-week
story: The make-up artist, who is a worldwide star on YouTube and Instagram, will star in the three-part series Jamie Genevieve: Great Indoors on BBC Scotland onThursday at . pm.It comes after the success of her first documentary for the networks BBC Scotland channel Jamie Genevieve #Unfiltered.The former Cathkin High School pupil started out working in make-up counters in Debenhams in Glasgow.Now she is known for her how to make-up demonstrations on YouTube.The new mini-series focuses on how Jamie and husband Jack is coping in the middle of the coronavirus pandemic from trying her hand at hairdressing to baking.

title: list-glasgow-shops-administration-lockdown

title: Country Life with Rosemary Goring  Away with the birds
story: It seems that spending spring and early summer in lockdown has turned the country into a nation of bird lovers. Itrsquos not just in the countryside that they have become a large part of our lives, a source of ersion, fascination and even, or so I have felt, of company. Stepping outside in the morning is like entering the Usher Hall during warm-up, a discordant and energetic orchestra of flutes, pipes and trumpets. As I brush my teeth, I sometimes see Wilf, the blackbird with the silver ankle ring, by the chimney, letting the wind ruffle his feathers. He has a very keen look, and when our eyes meet, you feel you have been noted. By evening, his spot is taken by a pair of turtle doves which perch side by side on the TV aerial, well camouflaged against the dusky sky.Alan saw Wilf enjoying a bath in a puddle the other day, near his HQ, in the centre of the village. On our first social gathering in months ndash a glass of wine in a neighbourrsquos garden one warm evening ndash Wilf landed on the lawn beside us, hopping behind our chairs, and unperturbed by our friendsrsquo inquisitive dog. Clearly he considers every garden to be his private food department. Theirs is Fortnum and Mason to our Lidl.A barn owl has been seen in the village lately, out hunting before dark. The photos show a beautul, ghostly creature with a heart-shaped pale face, after which Hoolet is named. It was gliding low between trees and across the edge of rough fields. I hope it kept its distance from the blue tits, because other birdsrsquo chicks are the perfect snack for owls and their owlets. That comes as little surprise, but it wasnrsquot till recently that I learned that the woodpeckers haunting our garden might be lingering near the nestbox in hope of a tasty snack. A large one had taken up position on the gatepost, a few days ago, within earshot of the nest. Squirrels, meanwhile, are the stuff of blue titsrsquo horror movies. They have been known to gnaw away at a nestbox entrance to reach the birds inside.The charm most of us find in bird le and nature is often a rose-tinted perspective. For birds, every day is a challenge, a survival exercise tougher than anything the SAS could conceive. Often Irsquoll see the older blue tits, decidedly dishevelled, stuffing themselves on our peanut feeders as they boost their blood sugar levels ahead of another caterpillar hunt. Occasionally a scattering of feathers in the flowerbeds indicate where a cat has brought down a weary or unwary bird. The RSPB says that the avian massacre by cats ndash estimated to be over  million a year ndash is a natural winnowing, with only the weak or ill falling prey. Irsquom not convinced. It sounds like a half-truth, aimed to prevent all-out conflict between bird and feline lovers. Not that the two are mutually exclusive.Danger is all around,yoursquore small and feathered. Friends were out for a walk beyond Hoolet recently, and spotted a flock of sparrows, feeding on grass-heads. Suddenly, not six feet away from them, a sparrowhawk swooped and snatched one of the birds. The speed of the attack, and the hawkrsquos audacity, were startling.Nor was this a first sighting of this turbo-charged predator that moves at the speed of a bullet. Occasionally I catch one ing between our house and a neighbourrsquos garden. As it flashes past the kitchen window, you know this is no idle reconnaissance. From its perch high in the sycamore, it has spied something delicious. The best you can hope is that, for the creature caught in its crosswires, the end is mercully swt.With less traffic, you see far fewer birds flattened on the roads, especially pheasants, which usually seem positively eager to examine the chassis of approaching cars. Our neighbours were nevertheless worried that theyrsquod found a pegged-out pheasant among their poppies. Hearing them calling to us through the beech hedge ndash by now almost as impenetrable as the Berlin Wall ndash we hurried over to offer first-aidrequired.The glittering, fearless ndash and pea-brained  ndash beauty, which has been parading our gardens since springtime, was far from dead. It had simply settled itself into an earthy dip to enjoy the sun. This would explain the dusty hollows Irsquove been finding of late in the shrubbery, asan easter egg-sized UFO had landed. Unfazed by the humans clucking anxiously around it, the pheasant only roused itself and got to its feet when it heard us approaching on the gravel.Another frequent visitor is the young hedgehog which has taken to walking up the road to the house, around tea-time, and disappearing into the back garden. Seeing it approach, I stuck my head out of the door into the pouring rain, and noticed it has a limp. Seen from behind, it lurched on one hind leg, like a trolley with a wonky wheel. Since it was going at a lick, and obviously knew exactly where it was heading, I left it to get on with it.Itrsquos a matter of days before the blue tits will be out of their nest, and bouncing around the garden. In a second-hand bookshop last year I found a guide to making your garden more bird friendly. In a chapter on building nestboxes for dferent species, it advised that, after the breeding season, these boxes must be cleaned, to protect future broods from disease. This must be how landlords feel when the end of a tenancy is approaching. The need to disinfect is clearly universal. Unique to providers of avian accommodation, however, is the warning to brace yourselves for finding addled eggs, or the remains of chicks that failed to thrive. You can be sure this task will fall to me.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald

title: POLITICS WATCH  Talking heads know when to stay quiet
story: The first series of monologues aired in  when the coat of one Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, was on a shoogly peg.When the next series came along a decade later, there was a newbie premier called Tony Blair in Downing Street.Here we are, , and another PM, Boris Johnson, is in office, future unknown, despite that thumping majority. His immediate task  The further easing of the lockdown in England without causing a surge in new cases.Ahead of the main act announcing something this week, Downing Street sent a warm-up man in the shape of Englandrsquos Health Secretary, Matt Hancock. On the dove-ish side of the lockdown easing debate, he was perhaps better placed than some to reassure the public that it would be safe to get back out there into pubs, restaurants, and schools.Sky Newsrsquos Ridge on Sunday was first to run the rule over the numbers with Mr Hancock. By presenter Sophy Ridgersquos reckoning, the contact tracers were only reaching two people a week.: Revolutionary vision for post-Covid ScotlandFar from being a sign of failure, said the Minister, this was a good thing. It showed there was spare capacity in the system, and that was because the number of new cases was falling.So to the much hyped app, meant to be the jewel at the centre of what the PM promised would be a ldquoworld-beating system of track and trace. With the failure of the Isle of Wight trial and still no date as to when the software will appear, the app has become a Bennettian ldquochip in the sugar, a sign of standards not being met and promises unfulfilled.Asked when the app would be ready, Mr Hancock said he was not going to put a date on it . ldquoIrsquom highly confident it will happen, said the Minister. By the time he reached The Andrew Marr Show this had become ldquoWersquoll get there with the app.Nick Robinson was standing in for Andrew Marr, whose father has died. The Today presenter was among those who deputised for the Scot after his stroke in . Robinson would have found the format much the same: start with the papers, end with a Minister, and pause in the middle for something lighter, in this case interviews with Kristen Scott Thomas, who stars in one of the Talking Heads, ldquoThe Hand of God, and Nicholas Hytner, who directs three of them.One major change Robinson could not have predicted are the by now regular slots on Marr for experts. Both Professor Sir Ian Diamond, the UKrsquos National Statistician, and Professor Peter Piot, director of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine stressed that coronavirus had not gone away and there was no room for complacency.Professor Piot, described in his introduction as something of a star in the fight against viruses ndash the ldquoMick Jagger of microbes someone had called him ndash said he would be okay with a relaxation of the two metre rule as long as masks were worn in public places. He also called the quarantining of people entering the UK ldquouseless and urged the UK Government to appoint a Covid- tsar at Cabinet level.: Former FMslates blended learningIn all his answers he was as clear as day, unlike Mr Hancock who had to do the usual thankless ministerial task of talking about a subject while not giving anything away before the official announcement.In lieu of detail Mr Hancock had come bearing a new word: ldquomitigations. Besides mask wearing this appeared to include adopting the New Zealand system of asking people for contact information when they go to a pub or restaurant. Expect ldquosign here for a pint headlines in England.Robinson was not going to let Mr Hancock go without bringing up the Ministerrsquos breach of the social distancing rules, as caught on camera last week when he patted a colleague on the back in the Commons. ldquoIt was just totally natural, said Mr Hancock. ldquoThis shows how dficult social distancing is. All I can do is say Irsquom incredibly sorry for this momentary breach. Itrsquos because Irsquom human. Wersquore all human. It sounded like another headline in the making.One person determined not to make the headlines was Iain Stewart, the new Scotland Office Minister, making his first appearance on Politics Scotland.Mr Stewart, the MP for Milton Keynes South, got his job because the previous incumbent had resigned over Dominic Cummingsrsquo dash to Durham. But Mr Stewart had little to nothing to say on that to host Gordon Brewer. Nor was he keen to share his thoughts on extending the furlough in Scotland save for telling the Scottish Government to be ldquomore ambitious on reviving the economy.ldquoAll yoursquore doing is telling us things we already know, said Brewer. Mr Stewart was still not for budging. He survived his baptism of fire, or baptism of Brewer, by sticking ruthlessly to his lines. Anyone would think he fancied a part in the next run of Talking Heads.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.News from trusted and credible sources is essential at all times, but especially now as the coronavirus pandemic impacts on all aspects of our lives. To make sure you stay informed during this dficult time our coverage of the crisis is free.However, producing The Heralds unrivalled analysis, insight and opinion on a daily basis still costs money and, as our traditional revenue streams collapse, we need your support to sustain our quality journalism.To help us get through this, wersquore asking readers to take a digital subscription to The Herald. You can sign up now for just pound for two months.If you choose to sign up, wersquoll offer a faster loading, advert-light experience ndash and deliver a digital version of the print product to your device every day. title: letters-eis-working-hard-come-best-solutions-scotlands-schools
story: As a member of the Education Recovery Group, the EIS, Scotlandrsquos largest education union, has sought to engage constructively with partners, including national and local government, about how we can best deliver for Scotlandrsquos students. It was an EIS survey of more than , teachers which first highlighted the negative impact of lockdown on our most disadvantaged pupils and the scale of the digital ide it was the EIS which raised the scandal of unemployed newly-qualied teacherswhen our schools need more teachers it was the EIS which called for an equity audit and for resources to be made available to mentor and tutor inidual students hit hardest by deprivation at a local level it has been the EIS which has driven the risk assessments necessary to make our schools safe places, for pupils and staff, when they re-open come August.And over this past week, as Scottish politics ed to its ldquonormal bickering worst, it has been the EIS which has called for a national effort to ensure that the money is found to deliver the teachers and resources needed for a sustained education recovery effort ndash an effort in which both the EIS and its members are keen to play a role.Larry Flanagan, General Secretary, Educational institute of Scotland, Edinburgh EH.AM I missing something  How is "blended learning" going to benefit the hard-working teaching profession  So far as I can see, it will mean doubling their workload and halving the amount of education the children will receive ndash is this what our once-lauded education system has come to My mother was teaching in the s and s in the east end of Glasgow ndash large classes of -, without the aid of a classroom assistant and extra special needs funding. It was her proud claim that not one of her children left without being able to read and write. Coincidentally, it seemed that the majority of them wanted to learn, teachers and parents were respected and discipline was applied rigorously, despite the widespread poverty.I find it dficult to understand why, in our modern system of free education, more and more children seem to prefer to roam the streets, rather than apply themselves to learning the basic Rs. Interestingly, the children of immigrants seem to appreciate this more than our home-grown lot.I wonder why this would be Carol MacDonald, Troon.POLITICIANS and high-ranking civil servants behind the decision for "blended" schooling, aka part-time school, are largely cushioned from the consequences of their decisions: they dont have to choose between working and educating their children at home because they have jobs where they can be flexible about hours, can afford for their partners not to work full-time, can afford private tutors or to send their children to private schools whichthey are not offering full-time schooling in August will still be offering much more than state schools.But it isnt just the children of politicians and high-ranking civil servants who are protected from the consequences of their decisions about lockdown. They, together with the scientists who are advising them, are not facing redundancy. Very many people employed in hospitality, retail and many other businesses in the private sector will lose their livelihoods as this protracted lockdown pans out these senior figures in the public sector wont.Linda Holt , Anstruther.WHEN I retired from teaching almost  years ago it was obvious that a signicant proportion of my colleagues did not enjoy the best of health. Sadly, I gather that is still the case in the teaching profession and I wonder how willing those pressing the First Minister to instantlyto pre-Covid-style education would be to accept responsibility for the teacher deaths and serious illness that might follow such a policy Teachers are not the most popular people on the planet, but they are not easily replaceable either. The current crisis could harm the education of our youth in more than one way.Ronald Cameron , Fort William.Read more: Newly qualied teachers offer help to blended learning model amid SNP fury at Scottish Government plans

title: members-pay-10-000-save-brora-golf-club
story: Clinging to the edge of the North Sea, dotted with trickling burns, challenging gulleys and electric fences at its perimeters to prevent hungry sheep from chewing on its greens, five time Open Champion Peter Thomson declared it to be among his favourite courses.So when the small lsquohidden gemrsquo golf club highlighted its concerns that the coronavirus crisis could topple it into oblivion, there were hopes that some golf fans might take pity and dig deep to help it through.Instead, the Sutherland club was met by a global wave of support that left its tiny shop swamped with orders and has boosted its finances by around pound, in just a few weeks.While shop staff battled to handle hundreds of orders for merchandise, donations and advance tee-time bookings, dozens of applications for new memberships flooded in.Among around  new members signing up to the Club, were seven who paid pound, each to become lsquoPlatinumrsquo members.And from fearing it might not survive the pandemic, the Club has now found itself overwhelmed by the response and the goodwill messages from around the world.ldquoIt was much better than we ever expected, said club General Manager Tony Gill.ldquoWe knew we have a good worldwide following, but it has been really nice to see how loyal that following is and how prepared they were to support us.The club, which sits around  miles north of Royal Dornoch and is the most northerly course designed by golf legend James Braid, was plunged into financial chaos as lockdown restrictions hit.Because of its remote location, it relies heavily on around pound, a year income from visitors to boost the pound, a year it receives in fees from its  memberships.ldquoWe did some projections at the end of March and looked at what our income might be depending on how long the lockdown lasted, compared to our costs, he added.ldquoThere was a big dference between the two figures, and not in a good way.ldquoWe put the message out to our members thatyou want a club to come back to, then we need income.ldquoNext thing it went around the world.Messages of support flowed into the clubrsquos social media pages from golf fans from the United States, Australia, South Africa and the Bahamas.Five-time Open champion Tom Watson, an honorary member of the club, tweeted his support, while social media influencers No Laying Up donated money through an exclusive towel sale.To boost funds, the club launched a series of fundraising offers, including letime and five-year hole sponsorship plans, club shop membership packages, a new pound international membership and the pound, Platinum le membership ndash with remarkable results.ldquoThe Platinum membership was designed for people who wanted to give us some extra money. Itrsquos a hefty chunk of money but we have been amazed at the response, added Mr Gill.Two of the Platinum memberships, which offer letime membership, a chance to have the memberrsquos name highlighted in the clubhouse, access to an annual Platinum membersrsquo event, and a gt of a tie or scarf, were sold to people with direct links to the Brora area.One, Bernard Ledworth, who moved to Brora in , told the clubrsquos website: ldquoSince I arrived in this small remote village, I soon realised how important visitors are to the survival of the golf club.ldquoLocal membership is small and membership fees remarkably low for a course of this quality. The golf club needed to reach out to its worldwide fan base, as well as its local members, in order to get financial aid.ldquoMany golf clubs worldwide will disappear over the next few months. We could not allow Brora to be one of them.ldquoBrora committee acting quickly, as they did, has given us a fighting chance of survival ndash but much more is needed.Another, Les Steel, who has family links to the area, said he had opted to buy the pound, membership rather than putting the money in the bank or stocks and shares. ldquoIrsquove effectively paid  years of golf at once, he added.Brora was established in  as a nine hole course and was extended in  to  holes.Five times Open Champion and prolic golf course designer James Braid visited the course in  and infor just pound plus travelling expenses, submitted plans for a redesigned -hole layout.The course is regarded as particularly challenging due to the North Sea wind and its natural obstacles.President Andy Stewart said: ldquoWe were looking forward to a bumper year of visitor numbers, projected at pound,, before the COVID- pandemic halted us in our tracks in March.ldquoWith a dependence on visitor income, we have had to be creative in our thinking to drive new revenue and we have simply been overwhelmed with the love for us from across the world.ldquoI think we always knew we had members and visitors who love our links. But, when that support all comes together at once, I think it has just been incredible for all of us to realise just how well regarded the golf club is.ldquoIt really has been fantastic.

title: opinion-mark-smith-agree-nicola---scots-looking-history-identity-wrong-way
story: Nicola Sturgeon touched on whatrsquos causing the issue the other day when she was asked whether black history should be included in the school curriculum. Yes it should, she said, because children need to have a better understanding of their identity and where they come from and Scotlandrsquos history, good and bad. ldquoAnd when it comes to colonialism and slavery, she said, ldquothere are aspects of Scotlandrsquos history that are pretty shameful and we have to be prepared to face up to that.I agree with Nicola. I also agree with the historian Tom Devine ndash who would dare do anything   ndash when he too said last week that Scots have failed to face up to their involvement in the slave trade and I agree with him about the reason for it: the Scottish sense of victimhood. ldquoIt is very dficult for a people who see themselves as victims, said Sir Tom, ldquoto accept that in their history they had also been oppressors.:Mark Smith: Staff are refusing to work on JK Rowlingrsquos new book because of her trans comments. Good on themBut this is where it gets complicated. Most of us would probably agree that a consensus is building that Scots need to do more to acknowledge and disseminate the fact that we were deeply involved in colonialism and slavery. Indeed, in his  book The Scottish Nation, Tom Devine goes further: not only were Scots involved in imperialism, the Scottish missionaries that were to the fore in Africa, India, and where gave it a moral imperative. In other words, not only were we up to our oxters in it, we convinced everyone that building a British empire was the right and moral thing to do Godrsquos work.The question is though: to what extent is a sense of victimhood, and a denial of the true picture, still a problem  Sir Tom believes things started to change in the s and that a greater interest in Scottishness led to a greater willingness by Scots to accept their past, but Irsquom inclined to agree with Nicola Sturgeon that the problem hasnrsquot really gone away and that therersquos more to do in facing up to the shameful parts of our past. Ms Sturgeon was talking about schools, but it doesnrsquot end there: therersquos politics, popular culture, social media, everywhere.And thatrsquos the problem with the tendency to turn away from the more shameful bits of history and see ourselves as victims ndash ones who suffer rather than ones who inflict suffering ndash because itrsquos pretty much there wherever you look. Many of our most celebrated historical figures are icons of suffering ndash Mary Queen of Scots in particular ndash but Irsquom afraid you can also see the same narrative in  in the way some nationalists argue for independence: we must be free, they say, because under the English we are suffering.This mentality of suffering is also particularly prevalent in the way Scots see conflict ndash a point well explained in a recent Zoom chat I sat in on involving some of the historians who belong to the Scots at War Living History Society. One of the great myths about the First World War, they said, is that Scots suffered more per capita than other parts of the UK and that the infantrymen who were sent over as canon fodder were disproportionately Scottish.:Mark Smith: What the row over Glasgows war memorials tells us about ourselvesNone of itrsquos true. Scots werenrsquot just infantrymen being sent over the top by English toffs, they were officers and doctors and they didnrsquot just serve in Scottish regiments. There were also Scots in the general staff and, of course, the man who was running the whole thing, Douglas Haig, was a Scot, the point being that there were Scots at the top of the British Army and at the top of British society and British government and theyrsquore still there today.Getting more Scots to accept this point is not going to be easy though, as one of the historians who took part in the Zoom call, James Taub, pointed out. When people have identied with a message all their lives, he said, theyrsquore going to be reluctant to change. Whatrsquos more, as Mr Taub said, much of the modern Scottish identity comes out of our perception of important historical events and the idea that Scots suffered more. History isnrsquot just who we were, itrsquos who we are, and thatrsquos true even when wersquove got the history wrong.Which leaves us with the dficult job of putting it right. Nicola Sturgeon is unlikely to agree that the tendency to see ourselves as victims rather than oppressors feeds into the way some nationalists frame the case for independence. But the First Minister does seem to be suggesting that wersquove been getting it wrong in the way we educate children about some of our history. In supporting the inclusion of black history in the curriculum, she also seems to be suggesting children need to know more about the role Scotland played in the oppression of colonialism and thatrsquos undoubtedly a good idea.:Mark Smith: Cruel and unjustied: the legal case against the Scottish Government that you might not have heard aboutHowever, it needs to go further than that because wersquore all guilty of telling the same, wrong story. We do it when we talk about English imperialists and donrsquot talk about Scottish ones. We do it when we talk about our lonely imprisoned queens and not our brutal warrior kings. And we do it when we talk about Scottish infantrymen on the Western Front and not the Scottish officers who were running the war.And we do it too, Irsquom afraid, when we talk today about Scots suffering in the shackles of the UK. The idea, I suppose, is that Scots have suffered disproportionately in the past and that wersquore still suffering now and in some ways, the story is understandable ndash the role of victim is better than the role of oppressor. But the truth is we have always been both and itrsquos time for what Nicola Sturgeon says she wants: a proper understanding of history, the story of the good and the bad, the story of who we were and who we are.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: no-swab-covid-saliva-test-trials-begin-uk-today
story: The no-swab test trials will see GP staff and other essential key workers testing themselves over four weeks, starting today.Saliva will be deposited into sample pots, and then collected by scientists to be analysed for current coronavirus infections.The trials are due to begin in Southampton, with the hope they could be rolled out across the UKsuccessful.GP staff, key workers, university employees and members of their households will be among the first groups to participate in the pilot, with test kits delivered either to their home or workplace for them to complete every week.They should receive the results within  hours.:Scottish developer of home Covid- test to step up workUK Government Health Secretary Matt Hancock said: ldquoSaliva testing could potentially make it even easier for people to take coronavirus tests at home, without having to use swabs."This trial will also help us learnroutine, at-home testing could pick up cases of the virus earlier.ldquoI am very grateful to everyone involved in the trial who is helping us develop our understanding of the virus which will benefit not only our but the global response to it.The UK Department for Health and Social care said these types of tests will help to increase the testing capacity for coronavirus, with initial results said to be "highly promising".:Coronavirus global spread accelerating as lockdown easesThe weekly tests are hoped to identy coronavirus cases earlier, including in people with no symptoms, or minor ones.Those who test positive will then be required to isolate for one or two weeks in their homes.Results will be shared with the UK Governments track and trace programme.

title: affluent-rural-areas-scotland-seeing-sharp-rise-unemployment
story: New data revealing for the first time the scale of job losses and furloughing that has brought the country to its knees during lockdown shows that nearly one in three are out of work.It reveals that some of Scotlands more affluent areas with historically lower levels of deprivation have seen the biggest rises in the numbers claiming either Jobseekers Allowanceor Universal Credit- being hit up to five times harder than those areas that are less well off.At least , Scots are now either claiming unemployment benefits or have been furloughed under the governments job retention scheme - that is nearly a third of the population who are available for work.The new data covering the three months from February , produced by Jobcentre Plus and Her Majestys Revenue and Customs, shows that the number of people claiming unemployment benefits has at least doubled in  out of the  Scottish Parliamentary constituencies.Some of the worst affected areas - are those which are reliant on the tourism and hospitality sector which has been crippled by the lockdown restrictions.:Alarm bells as Scotlands unemployment rate becomes highest of UK nationsThe cuts are no respecter of wealth, with Edinburgh Southern the constituency of mainly leafy Victorian town-housing based around the suburbs of Newington, Morningside, Craiglockhart, Blackford and Merchiston the nations claimant rate rise hotspot, with the number claiming benefits more than trebling .The Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch constituency of finance secretary Kate Forbes, that is heavily reliant on tourism, came a close second with a .% rise in claimants over the three months.Claire Telfer , head of Scotland at Save the Children fears the worst may yet be to come.ldquoThese figures highlight that the pandemic lsquonightmarersquo is far from over and the financial impacts of the crisis are being felt acutely by families across many parts of the country. Wersquove seen huge increases in families claiming social security support, piling financial pressures on families who can least afford it. Parents are struggling to make ends meet and are already cutting back on food and essentials," she said."As the job retention scheme tapers off, we fear further unemployment and hardship ahead. Social security should be an anchor in stormy times, putting more money in familiesrsquo pockets."It comes as research by Save the Children and the Joseph Rowntree Foundation found that seven in ten of Scotlands poorest families have had to cut back on food and other essentials while half have had to borrow money to get through the coronavirus lockdown.More than half of families on Universal Credit or Child Tax Credit in Scotland have been pushed to borrow money since start of crisis ndash with many relying on expensive forms of credit.Ms Telfer added that they are calling on the UK Government to provide a leline for children by increasing the child element of Universal Credit and Child Tax Credits by pound per week. They are also calling on the Scottish Government and councils to provide a "dignied, cash-first approach" to free school meals over the summer holidays.Across Scotland the claimant count has soared by % from , to ,.Eastwood, which had the lowest levels of unemployment on the Scottish mainland saw numbers rise by two-and-three-quarters- the third highest of all  constituencies.The analysis also reveals that the region with the smallest rise in claimants at just .% is an area with already high levels of unemployment - Greenock and Inverclyde. In , the Inverclyde council area was rated as the most deprived in Scotland by the Scottish Index of Multiple Deprivation , with Greenock Town Centre the most deprived community.And there is an east-west ide in terms of the effect of Covid- unemployment, with the six Edinburgh constituencies seeing a rise in claimants typically running at two-and-a-half times over the three months - about half the rate in Glasgow which has seen a % increase.Dave Moxham, deputy general secretary of the Scottish Trades Union Congress said it feared a disproportionate unemployment hit to fall on young people going forward with the October end of the furlough scheme presenting a "clf edge" with government either forced to accept very high employment or to act to invest in jobs.ldquoThe spike in unemployment and the impending furlough clf edge underline the fragility of the Scottish economy with its high reliance on the service sector. The coronavirus crisis has been layered on to an economic system that wasnrsquot working. Large parts of Scotland have never recovered from industrial decline, relying on out-of-town shopping centres to inflate a local economy built on consumer debt, while other parts are dependent on the low-waged tourism and hospitality sector which is unlikely to recover anytime soon."Liz Cameron , chief executive of the Scottish Chambers of Commerce said that to prevent mass unemployment, support needs to be aimed at sectors such as renewable energy where there can be growth.She said the UK should align unemployment benefits to reskilling and retraining focused on sectors such as decarbonisation, green energy, manufacturing and digital which is expected to show growth going forward."There is no easy fix, but we need to remain focussed, party politics aside, to tackle the global economic and jobs crisis we face," she said."Scotlandrsquos economy has proven particularly vulnerable to the effects of the pandemic. This is in part due to Scotlandrsquos heavy reliance in certain sectors, for example tourism and our independent retail and hospitality businesses in particular. They were the first to close down and are at the end of the road map to be able to restart completely.ldquoWe have already seen major employers such as Rolls Royce and several major hoteliers forced to enter discussions on redundancy which will inevitably mean even more job losses.ldquoThis situation has been partly shielded by the financial support provided to businesses through the UK Governmentrsquos Jobs Retention Scheme. With this financial support being reduced and finally withdrawn, businesses being unable to trade, earning no income to pay wages, there is no viable alternative. The unemployment situation in Scotland is also compounded by the fact that we tend to lag behind other parts of the UK in terms of economic performance even before the pandemic.ldquoWe also need quick solutions targeted in the right areas to support those graduates and school leavers who are just entering the employment market. We will need to roll-out retraining and upskilling modules that are quick and agile that match up with the needs of Scotlandrsquos economic sectors. Only by aligning our workforce and the needs of the economy will we be able to help large numbers of iniduals to keep their jobs and secure new ones. Anything less will do permanent damage to the economy and to our skills base. "Last week it emerged that Scotlands unemployment rate was now the highest among all the UK nations.The Office for National Statisticssaid unemployment in Scotland for people over  was .%, compared with a UK rate of .%.Unemployment rose by rose by , to , between February and April as lockdown hit the labour market.And ministers said the figures were a clear indication of the challenge facing Scotland as a result of the pandemic.Scotlands unemployment rate went up from .% in the previous quarter.Meanwhile the latest figures show Englands rate now stands at .%, Wales is at % and Northern Ireland is at .%.The figures only captured the first five weeks of lockdown.AScottishGovernment spokesman said: "We know the scale of the challenge facingScotland as a result of the coronavirus pandemic and understand that many people will be feeling a deep sense of anxiety about their livelihoods. Keeping people in work while supporting those who have lost theirjobswill continue to be at the heart of our thinking as we carefully reopen the economy. However, it is essential that protecting public health is an absolute priority and it is only by properly suppressing the virus that we will achieve a sustainable economic recovery.ldquoThe impact of Covid- has been enormous on both businesses and iniduals and theScottishGovernment has so far spent more than pound billion tackling its effects, including a pound million Return to Work package to help stimulateScotlandrsquos economy.ldquoScotlandrsquos labour market has changed drastically since the lockdown measures were imposed. Tackling unemployment is our priority as we emerge from the coronavirus crisis. Four Ministers chaired a Labour Market Summit with Skills DevelopmentScotland and theScottish Funding Council yesterday afternoon to ensure a co-ordinated approach to helping people acrossScotland back into workldquoWhile theScottishGovernment has welcomed the support schemes from HMRC during this time, and their extension, it is important that we ensure this support continues to be offered for as long as required, particularly in sectors such as tourism, hospitality, retail, culture, and oil and gas, which will not have fully recovered by October. That is why we are urging the UKGovernment to work with us to ensure support reflects what is required inScotland. Failure to do so will put the economy at a competitive disadvantage in recovering from this crisis, and could result in additional job losses. We must not allow that to happen.

title: new-prehistoric-circle-discovered-near-stonehenge
story: Evidence of  or more massive prehistoric shafts, which measure more than ten metres in diameter and five metres deep, forming a circle of more than two kilometres in diameter has been revealed.The coring of the shafts suggests that the features are Neolithic - meaning they were excavated around the time Durrington Walls was built more than  years ago.It is thought the shafts served as a boundary to a sacred area or precinct associated with the henge.Experts from the University of St Andrews were joined by counterparts from institutes including Birmingham, Warwick, the University of Wales Trinity Saint David and the Scottish Universities Environmental Research Centre .:Summer solstice in Scotland - what is it and how can you mark it Dr Richard Bates, of the universityrsquos School of Earth and Environmental Sciences, said: ldquoYet again, the use of a multidisciplinary effort with remote sensing and careful sampling is giving us an insight to the past that shows an even more complex society than we could ever imagine.ldquoClearly sophisticated practices demonstrate that the people were so in tune with natural events to an extent that we can barely conceive in the modern world we live in today.Tim Kinnaird, of the same school, said: ldquoThe sedimentary infills contain a rich and fascinating archive of previously unknown environmental information.ldquoWith optically stimulated luminescence profiling and dating, we can write detailed narratives of the Stonehenge landscape for the last , years.The announcement of the discovery comes after the Summer Solstice, which took place online this year with the annual gathering cancelled due to coronavirus.English Heritage has provided access to the event since  but warned visitors not to travel to the BC Neolithic monument this year.Dr Nick Snashall, National Trust archaeologist for the Stonehenge and Avebury World Heritage Site, hailed the ldquoastonishing discovery.:Stonehenge welcomes summer solsticeHe said: ldquoAs the place where the builders of Stonehenge lived and feasted Durrington Walls is key to unlocking the story of the wider Stonehenge landscape, and this astonishing discovery offers us new insights into the lives and beliefs of our Neolithic ancestors.ldquoThe Hidden Landscapes team have combined cutting-edge, archaeological fieldwork with good old-fashioned detective work to reveal this extraordinary discovery and write a whole new chapter in the story of the Stonehenge landscape.

title: face-masks-become-mandatory-public-transport-scotland-today
story: Scotlands Transport Secretary has urged those looking to travel this week to leave space for those who need it most and limit their journeys.As phase two of Scotlands route map out of lockdown gets underway, Michael Matheson urged employed to careful manage their phased ing of staff, as early figures suggest up to % of employees could travel to the workplace in this phase.This is compared to a figure of just % when full lockdown was in place.The increased travel could result in a surge in the number of passengers by around a third from the current number of just, per day.ScotRail hasannounced it will provide face masks for free at more than a dozen stations on Monday.:ScotRail to offer free face masks at some stations as coverings become mandatoryMr Matheson said: ldquoFirst of all I want to pay tribute to those transport operators and workers who have kept Scotlandrsquos key workers moving in recent months, during an incredibly testing time.ldquoWe are now in a position to enter phase two of the route map, however we must do so with great caution, as we cannot risk a resurgence of the virus and wasting all of the good work to date in terms of respecting boundaries and working from home.ldquoTransport has a vital role to play in helping restart the economy, but there is a clear and great need for personal and collective responsibility when travelling, especially by public transport.ldquoItrsquos also very important to leave space on public transport for those who need it most.ldquoPassengers who must travel will notice some major changes at our bus and train stations and transport hubs.ldquoMore hand sanitisers, physical distancing measures, posters and information points, and, crucially, you should be wearing a face covering.A Survation poll for the charity Advice Direct Scotland on Sunday also found just over two-thirdswere not comfortable using public transport after lockdown with % comfortableMr Matheson added: ldquoRemember capacity will be around  to % of normal, even when full services resume.ldquoThat is why all passengers have to wear a face covering.:Face coverings dont make you invincible amid warning over Boxing Day sales scenes as shops re-openldquoI continue to engage directly with business leaders and major employers and I am encouraging them to embrace these changes which can help us all adapt to a new working and business environment.ldquoWe are increasing the frequency of public transport, but without a signicant reduction in demand, the plan wonrsquot work.ldquoI am pleased that we are already seeing some real ambition from local authorities and partners in terms of redesigning the landscape and infrastructure around our towns and cities, supported by Scottish Government funding, and I look forward to seeing more of these measures being rolled out over the coming weeks and months.

title: five-strict-scotrail-rules-face-coverings-become-mandatory-public-transport

title: sewage-tested-traces-covid-19-monitor-spread-virus-scotland
story: As part of the trial, samples from waste water at treatment works in each of the  NHS Scotland health board areas will be analysed by Scottish Environment Protection Agencyscientists.They are building on exploratory work started by Scottish Water and academic partners from the University of Edinburghs Roslin Institute to monitor the levels of fragments of Covid- ribonucleic acidin waste water.Experts hope the data could help understand trends in the prevalence and distribution of the virus in Scotland, in combination with community testing and hospital admissions data.:No-swab Covid saliva test trials begin in the UK todaySepa chief executive Terry AHearn said: "As one of the first European Environmental Protection Agencies to do so, were in the early stages of this exploratory work to trace the presence of coronavirus RNA in Scotlands waste water."Our expertise in designing and implementing monitoring networks, coupled with our scientic capabilities, meant that we were able to get up and running quickly with the support of our partners. We believe we are one of the first agencies in Europe to begin this work."Our hope is that our analysis could provide useful data in Scotlands efforts to trace the virus."Sepa estimates the samples will represent waste water from between % and % of the Scottish population.The project has the backing of the Scottish Government and Health Protection Scotland.The first waste water samples from eight health board areas are now being analysed in Sepas Lanarkshire Angus Smith laboratories.The World Health Organisation has said there is currently no evidence that coronavirus has been transmitted via sewerage systems.Dr Alexander Corbishley, of the Roslin Institute, said: "Detecting viral genetic material in waste water is relatively easy however, the challenge is measuring how much genetic material is present accurately and relating that to disease levels in the community."Sepa said funding from the Centre of Expertise for Waters , which is supported by the Scottish Government, has allowed scientists in Scotland to work with academic colleagues across the UK to keep pace with international developments in the rapidly expanding field of wastewater epidemiology.:Scottish developer of home Covid- test to step up workEnvironment Secretary Roseanna Cunningham said: "The Covid- pandemic has been an unprecedented global crisis which has fundamentally affected us all."There has of course been much research work carried out globally to better monitor, assess and understand the virus."Such work is crucial to ensure our recovery and I welcome this important project being undertaken by Sepa, Scottish Water, academia and other partners to monitor the prevalence of the virus across the Scottish population."

title: hundreds-scots-queue-early-hours-ikea-opens-stores-first-time-three-months
story: The Swedish homeware store opened its doors for the first time since lockdown began in March, after being forced to shut due to the ongoing coronavirus crisis.They announced last week plans to reopen their stores in Glasgow and Edinburgh, as well as their collection point in Aberdeen, on Monday, June .:Ikea announces opening date for Scottish stores with new safety measures in placeAnd the countrys two main stores in Straiton and Braehead saw hundreds of keen furniture shoppers from as early as .am - almost four hours before the shops opened.Pic: SWNSIn Edinburgh, around  people were seen queuing, with the store having the capacity for  people to stay in line with coronavirus guidelines.Metal barriers and yellow dots showed people where to queue while maintaining social distancing, and some shoppers wore face masks in preparation for browsing.Stewards in high-vis yellow jackets were on hand to make sure people obeyed the rules.Stricter safety measures are in place indoors, ranging from one-way systems to social distance wardens throughout the stores.Pic: SWNSPeter Jelkeby, UKIE Country CEO and CSO, said: ldquoAs we look to warmly welcome customers and co-workers back into our stores inScotland, theirhealthand safety remain our top priority, and thatrsquos why wersquove put in place extensive measures to ensure their safety and comfort.:Ikea to reopen  UK stores after closing due to coronavirus"This range of comprehensive measures has been implemented in accordance with government guidelines, as well as building on learnings from other IKEA countries that have reopened ahead of us.ldquoWhile the experience might be a little dferent to before ndash itrsquos the same IKEA, with the vision to ldquocreate a better everyday le for the many people, and the ambition to inspire people through our brilliant affordable range and home furnishing advice.ldquoThroughout lockdown, wersquove had the unique privilege of being a part of peoplersquos everyday lives at home, and wersquore committed to continuing doing whatever we can to support our customers and co-workers on this next part of the journey we take together.

title: scotlands-largest-theme-park-m-ds-saved-administration
story: News broke last month that the much-loved theme park in Strathclyde had gone under following years of financial struggle, made worse by the impact of the coronavirus pandemic.But now, bosses have confirmed that the centre is now under new management - and the park will reopen when lockdown restrictions are lted."We are delighted to announce that Scotlandrsquos Theme Park has been bought out of administration and has new management in place," a statement on social media read."In line with Scottish Government guidelines, we are working hard behind the scenes to be able to reopen Scotlandrsquos Theme Park as well as Devilrsquos Island Adventure Golf, and Amazonia when restrictions have been lted."We are working within the physical distancing guidelines as outlined by the Scottish Government, as well as introducing additional hand sanitising stations located throughout the park and Amazonia and look forward to welcoming you back in the near future."There will be some modications when you come back to visit us and wersquod ask that you bear with us during this period of change and adjustment to allow us to give you the fantastic day out you would usually experience at Scotlandrsquos Theme Park."More follows

But we mustnrsquot allow ourselves to think the risk has gone away, or become complacent in any way.""@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Sturgeon reiterates need to be cautious to avoid coronavirus second wave","description": "Sturgeon reiterates need to be cautious to avoid coronavirus second wave","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media DyxEfCQ poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests DyxEfCQ.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": :Coronavirus: Swinney to make parliamentary statement about schools crisisIt was reported today that there has been no new Covid- deaths recorded in Scotland for the second day in a row, however, trends show that this is usually the case over the weekend.At the daily press briefing, Nicola Sturgeon said: ldquoThe virus hasnrsquot gone away, there are already countries ndash China and Germany for example ndash that are right now dealing with spikes in cases as a result of signicant outbreaks. And health officials in South Korea have said they think the country is now experiencing a second wave.ldquoI know that when numbers of cases and deaths here are continuing to fall it is very tempting for all of us to think it is all over and we should just now quickly get back to normal.ldquoWe are trying to get back to normal and we want to do that as quickly as possible, but let me reiterate my strong view that acting recklessly now would be a serious mistake.ldquoWe must continue to be cautious and all of us must continue to adhere strictly to the public health advice. That will help us continue progress and avoid a resurgence of the virus now.ldquoBut it will also hopefully put us in a much stronger position ahead of the winter months to come.Another reminder that the virus hasnrsquot gone away. Our exit from lockdown is underway and with a fair wind I hope wersquoll be able to speed up aspects of it. But we mustnrsquot allow ourselves to think the risk has gone away, or become complacent in any way. https:t.co yOFYlNggeDespite clear progress in containing the virus in some regions, especially those that saw early outbreaks, globally the number of new virus cases has soared in recent days in countries such asBrazil, Iraq, India and the United States.Nearly nine million people have been infected and more than , people have died, according to figures compiled by Johns Hopkins University.Experts say the actual numbers are much higher, given limits to testing and the presumed large share of asymptomatic cases.The Philippines has reported more than , infections and , deaths, among the highest in south-east Asia, and is struggling to help bring home tens of thousands of Filipinos who have lost their work worldwide due to coronavirus lockdowns and economic downturns.In Iraq, masked workers were setting up makesht coronavirus wards in Baghdadrsquos vast exhibition grounds as a long-dreaded spike in infections strained its overstretched hospitals, battered by years of conflict and poor infrastructure.On Sunday, the World Health Organisation reported the largest single-day increase in coronavirus cases by its count, at more than , new cases in the latest  hours. Brazil tallied , and the US was next at ,, the UN health agency said. More than two-thirds of the new deaths were reported in the Americas.In east Asia there were signs of progress as South Korea reported  new cases, the first time its daily increase fell to under  in nearly a month.The country has been reporting  to  new cases per day in the past few weeks, amid increased public activity, eased attitudes on social distancing and an uptick in imported cases.Elsewhere in Asia, Beijingrsquos increase was in single digits for the first time in eight days. It reported nine cases.Even in New Zealand, which earlier said it had eliminated local transmissions of the virus, two new cases were reported on Monday among infected people arriving from India and Pakistan. The country of five million people now has nine active cases after having none at all earlier this month.

title: far-can-travel-scotlands-phase-2-can-drive-england
story: Early on in her briefing, Nicola Sturgeon said that as part of the ldquostaged approach, the Scottish Government guidance will continue to be asking people to ldquoas far as possible to stay within or close to their local area.She added that their ambition ldquois to be in a position to lt this in Phase  and in time for the proposed resumption of tourism from July .How far can I travel At this stage for leisure and recreation purposes, Ms Sturgeon says people should ldquonot travel more than five miles or so from their home.She added: ldquoOutdoor businesses, such as zoos and garden attractions, can also reopen from June  ndash although people should not be travelling more than five miles to visit them and tickets should be bought in advance.The retail sector is also set to open on June .However she added that, as revealed previously, the five-mile limitdoes NOT apply to meeting family and friends.These meetings should take place outdoors, but under new Phase  measures you can go inside to use the toilet.Can I travel to England A Scottish Government spokesperson says that as long as you can get there and back in one day, you can visit family in England.They told the Scotsman that it would be fine to travel to, for example, Carlisle or Berwick, to visit family ndash so long as you do not have to stay overnight.The spokesman did however advise against travelling too far, adding it would become more dficult to make it back in one day ndash urging people to ldquoexercise common sense in their actions.Can I use public transport Public transport is continuing to operate at a massively reduced capacity to allow for physical distancing.But under Phase , there will be a slight increase in services ndash but with new rules.From today, face coverings are mandatory on all public transport in Scotland, with customers urged to avoid peak times wherever possible to allow for key workers to use the services.

perform at a partnership level due to the smaller numbers involved."Mr ODowd and Mr Burton state: "In the early part of the pandemic, the SMR [standardised mortality ratio] for Inverclyde is far higher than that of NHS GGC but the dference at this point was not statistically signicant in comparison with NHS GGC rates."We can therefore see that with standardisation for age, sex and deprivation, whilst a higher mortality rate remains, the dference may have arisen by chance."Thereport into Covid- deaths in Inverclyde reveals that the weekly death rate peaked in the week beginning April , with  people losing their lives.A total of  people have died in the area as a result ofcoronavirus.Analysis of all available information for the report shows that there was an earlier rise in Inverclyde compared with other areas.The report reads: "It is considered likely that the rates were much higher than recorded due to testing criteria and availability early in the pandemic.":Coronavirus: How Inverclyde became the worst-hit area in Scotland"There is some evidence that the COVID- positive testing rate was higher in Inverclyde than in other areas."The report adds: "The most likely scenario which explains the excess deaths in Inverclyde is that the pandemic took hold earlier in Inverclyde in comparison with other areas of Scotland and NHS GGC."This fits with the higher positive rates of COVID- testing in Inverclyde, and with the higher admission rates of patients with COVID- in Inverclyde."This most likely reflects the early nature of the pandemic experience in Inverclyde, and a greater propensity to admit cases where there was no experience of their clinical needs at an early stage of the pandemic."There is no evidence that the quality of care or access to care was worse in Inverclyde, as the admission rates were higher than across the rest of NHS GGC, and there was no dference in the death rates from those in Inverclyde admitted with COVID- in comparison with NHS GGC as a whole."
